course."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ARCH1080 - Introduction to Architecture and Enabling Skills","description":"

ARCH1080 supports the development of foundational skills for architectural research and thinking. The course is focussed on exemplary modern and contemporary architects and their buildings. These form the basis of three discreet yet interdependent ‘case study’ projects. The first two projects aim to develop student skills in architectural description. The third project aims to develop student skills in the analysis and interpretation of architectural strategies. Together they teach elementary tools for the study and communication of architectural ideas and meaning.

contentlets.description: ARCH1080 supports the development of foundational skills for architectural research and thinking. The course is focussed on exemplary modern and contemporary architects and their buildings. These form the basis of three discreet yet interdependent ‘case study’ projects. The first two projects aim to develop student skills in architectural description. The third project aims to develop student skills in the analysis and interpretation of architectural strategies. Together they teach elementary tools for the study and communication of architectural ideas and meaning.
contentlets.title: Introduction to Architecture and Enabling Skills

course."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ARCH1101 - Architectural Design Studio 1","description":"

This studio lays down the disciplinary foundations for architectural design. Through small scale and experimental design projects, the course introduces the main concepts and activities of architectural design – that is, making and thinking of human inhabitation, including space, form, order, structure, material, scale, proportion, as well as the relation between plan, section and elevation. The studio introduces manual and digital forms of representation as design tools.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"3adf564bdba53450be4672f5f396194c","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Experiment 2: Final","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"60","description":"

Students are advised to imagine they are the Dean of a school of Architecture, Computational Design, or Engineering.  There challenge is to design a school that forms a bridge spanning buildings in an urban environment.  Students will be asked to design two moving elements that modify the students view of the school when they see it from locations on the ground plane vs locations above ground level. 

Feedback will be provided via Review within 10 days of submission 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f6df564bdba53450be4672f5f396194e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"f6df564bdba53450be4672f5f396194f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"fedf564bdba53450be4672f5f396194d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"fedf564bdba53450be4672f5f396194e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"fedf564bdba53450be4672f5f396194f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"17df564bdba53450be4672f5f3961957","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Experiment 1: Final","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Students are asked to choose a specific work from two of the three companies listed in the course outline and and create an architecture consisting of three spaces; one below ground, one above ground and one on the ground plane. The spaces above and below ground are the clients studio workshops  The space on the ground plane is a place for selling the work. Students are asked to create a stair that allows each client to bring their completed work to the showroom on the ground plane in a distinctive and significant way.  Experiment 1 Final is the complete chair model.

Feedback will be provided via Review within 10 days of submission 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f6df564bdba53450be4672f5f396194e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"fedf564bdba53450be4672f5f396194d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"fedf564bdba53450be4672f5f396194e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"fedf564bdba53450be4672f5f396194f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9fdf564bdba53450be4672f5f3961976","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Experiment 1: Conceptual Model","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

Students are asked to choose a specific work from two of the three companies listed in the course outline and and create an architecture consisting of three spaces; one below ground, one above ground and one on the ground plane. The spaces above and below ground are the clients studio workshops  The space on the ground plane is a place for selling the work. Students are asked to create a stair that allows each client to bring their completed work to the showroom on the ground plane in a distinctive and significant way.  Experiment 1 is producing a conceptual model.

Feedback will be provided via Review within 10 days of submission 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f6df564bdba53450be4672f5f396194e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"fedf564bdba53450be4672f5f396194d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"fedf564bdba53450be4672f5f396194e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"fedf564bdba53450be4672f5f396194f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b6df564bdba53450be4672f5f3961951","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/ARCH1101.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"","links":[]}

course."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ARCH1102 - Architectural Design Studio 2","description":"

Through the study of selected canonical buildings in their conceptual exploration, architectural thematisation, spatial figuration, and the logic of material & structural expression, this studio centres around how architectural space is configured and refined for use. Site condition and material limits are introduced to the design process. The architectural relations between interior and exterior are established according to the use, circulation and room types; the development of the project within constraints and possibilities of construction techniques; and the site conditions. The design will be aided through basic digital fabrication.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"9affde4bdba53450be4672f5f3961994","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project 1: Kiosk in the Courtyard","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

This project addresses the design and development of a temporary structure guided by the interpretation of the design brief. Assessing site conditions, mode of construction and suitability of materials used are to be explored in its initial phase, followed by the complete design resolution of the final proposal.

Assessment will include a presentation with verbal feedback and written comments + suggestions given to each student project.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d2ffde4bdba53450be4672f5f3961996","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"d2ffde4bdba53450be4672f5f3961997","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d2ffde4bdba53450be4672f5f3961998","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"daffde4bdba53450be4672f5f3961996","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"daffde4bdba53450be4672f5f3961997","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"66ffde4bdba53450be4672f5f39619a7","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project 2: Bicycle Parking and Workshop","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

This project addresses the design and development of bycycle parking solutions and development of design brief. Assessing site conditions, mode of construction and suitability of materials used are to be explored in its innitial phase, followed by the complete design resolution of the final proposal.

Assessment will include a presentation with verbal feedback and written comments + suggestions given to each student project.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d2ffde4bdba53450be4672f5f3961996","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"d2ffde4bdba53450be4672f5f3961997","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d2ffde4bdba53450be4672f5f3961998","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"daffde4bdba53450be4672f5f3961996","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"daffde4bdba53450be4672f5f3961997","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"aaffde4bdba53450be4672f5f3961999","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project 3: Gallery Tower Ensemble","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"60","description":"

This project addresses how a vertical gallery design can bring project one and two together architectually as an ensemble. Assessing site conditions, mode of construction and suitability of materials used are to be explored in its innitial phase, followed by the complete design resolution of the final proposal: the ensemble of project one, two and three. 

it consists of two parts:

Part I  - Digital Fabrication Draft Review: testing design solution by employing digital fabrication models

exhibition + silent presentation + verbal feedback + peer review + written suggestions

Part II  - Final Project Review

presentation + verbal feedback; written concluding comments + suggestions

course."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ARCH1161 - Architectural Science and Building Environment 1","description":"

This course introduces students to the design strategies and scientific understanding needed to minimise buildings’ impact on natural resources and the environment. It includes life-cycle thinking in architectural design, a history of environmental design concepts in architecture, understanding and responding to climate, design innovation, solar architecture, building fabric performance and wind, ventilation and cooling. In completing the course, students will master the basic techniques to reduce building-related carbon emissions and enhance human comfort through climate-sensitive design. In addition, they will gain the ability to analyse climatic and geomorphological context to optimise building design for sun, temperature, wind, human metabolism and perception.

course."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ARCH1162 - Construction and Structures 1","description":"

This course is an introduction to the foundations of architectural construction and structures. It investigates the history and significance of building materials and the perception of architectural spaces in relation to their use. The structural, environmental and design implications of material characteristics and physical properties are explored in relation to masonry, concrete, timber, steel and glass. The construction of primary buildings elements including foundations, flooring, walls, openings, fenestration, roofing, stairs and lifts and their application in domestic settings are introduced. The conventions of construction drawings, relevant quality and performance standards and communication of relevant construction information are explored through case studies.

contentlets.description: This course is an introduction to the foundations of architectural construction and structures. It investigates the history and significance of building materials and the perception of architectural spaces in relation to their use. The structural, environmental and design implications of material characteristics and physical properties are explored in relation to masonry, concrete, timber, steel and glass. The construction of primary buildings elements including foundations, flooring, walls, openings, fenestration, roofing, stairs and lifts and their application in domestic settings are introduced. The conventions of construction drawings, relevant quality and performance standards and communication of relevant construction information are explored through case studies.

course."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ARCH1201 - Architectural Design Studio 3","description":"

Various concepts and architectural devices of modern architecture are studied through drawings and models, and against a pre-modern background. The notion of a design program is introduced as a meaningful human narrative. More complex inhabitation is examined through experimental design problems, as well as through projects of moderate programmatic, spatial, and material complexity in a defined urban site.


 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"73102e8bdba53450be4672f5f39619ce","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project 1- Positioning","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

Questioning Project Site/Context/Precedents/ Brief

Testing Design Concept for Low Carbon Living

Evidence and ability to:

  1. researching, analyzing and questioning site, context, precedents of terrace house projects and design brief for low carbon living through notated graphic diagrams, drawings and study models
  2. testing design concept ideas for low carbon living through notated graphic diagrams, drawings and study models.

Verbal feed-back and Written feedback in Moodle

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"f7102e8bdba53450be4672f5f39619d0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f7102e8bdba53450be4672f5f39619d1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f7102e8bdba53450be4672f5f39619d2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ff102e8bdba53450be4672f5f39619d0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"40206e8bdba53450be4672f5f3961920","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project 2 - Strategy","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Potential of Low Carbon Living project at a Schematic Design Level

Evidence and ability to:

  1. exploring design ideas for low carbon living through study models, notated scaled diagrams and drawings based on your site investigation, low carbon brief/program analysis and lessons drawn from the analysis of precedents and low carbon living
  2.  identifying a clear low carbon living architectural strategy
  3. elaborating the potential of your low carbon living project through a schematic design

Verbal feed-back and Written feedback in Moodle

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f7102e8bdba53450be4672f5f39619d1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f7102e8bdba53450be4672f5f39619d2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"ff102e8bdba53450be4672f5f39619cf","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ff102e8bdba53450be4672f5f39619d0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ff102e8bdba53450be4672f5f39619d1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b7106e8bdba53450be4672f5f3961912","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project 3 - Proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"60","description":"

Defending the Rationale of the Low Carbon Living project at a Developed Design Level

Evidence and ability to:

  1. developing an articulated and clear low carbon final design proposal based on an integrated understanding of site and program in an urban condition
  2. demonstrating an elementary knowledge of low carbon concrete construction

Verbal feed-back and Written feedback in Moodle

course."}],"credit_points_header":"12 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ARCH1203 - Architectural Design Studio 4","description":"

This studio focuses on the design of adaptable, dynamic built spaces and landscapes on a dramatic Sydney foreshore site with indigenous and industrial heritage. It builds upon your work in previous design studios in the Architecture Program. You will need to bring your accumulated design knowledge to this studio in order to negotiate a major transition in terms of scale and complexity. This studio involves a major shift from a series of highly defined sites to a broader landscape, from a private program to a public program, from single buildings and landscapes to multiple buildings and landscapes, and from a series of discrete projects to one major design project.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"b230e6cbdba53450be4672f5f3961936","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Second Design Proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

The Second Design Proposal involves the preparation of a developed design proposal that answers the brief in its entirety. It builds upon the First Design Proposal and increases in complexity to achieve a level of resolution across the whole site at 1:200 and is further articulated through a carefully curated collection of experimental material models at 1:50. It is supported by an extensive narrative document that incorporates diagrams, drawings, developmental imagery and critical texts.

Verbal feedback in studio; audio feedback in studio and/or Moodle; written feedback in Moodle; peer critique in studio.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"f630e6cbdba53450be4672f5f3961937","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f630e6cbdba53450be4672f5f3961938","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f630e6cbdba53450be4672f5f3961939","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"fe30e6cbdba53450be4672f5f3961936","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"fe30e6cbdba53450be4672f5f3961937","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"fe30e6cbdba53450be4672f5f3961938","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0f30e6cbdba53450be4672f5f3961940","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"First Design Proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

The First Design Proposal involves the preparation of a preliminary design proposal at 1:200 that answers part of the brief. It develops the core idea expressed in the Radical Model, and begins to explore its extension across the different areas of the site. Like the Radical Model, it is informed by the forming and casting workshops and also includes an accompanying series of experimental material models at 1:50. It is supported by a developed narrative document that incorporates diagrams, drawings, developmental imagery and critical texts.

Verbal feedback in studio; audio feedback in Moodle; peer critique in studio; formal visual and verbal feedback lecture.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"f630e6cbdba53450be4672f5f3961937","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f630e6cbdba53450be4672f5f3961938","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f630e6cbdba53450be4672f5f3961939","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"fe30e6cbdba53450be4672f5f3961936","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"fe30e6cbdba53450be4672f5f3961937","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"fe30e6cbdba53450be4672f5f3961938","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8b30e6cbdba53450be4672f5f3961948","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Radical Model","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

The Radical Model is an exercise focusing on the production of a working model and accompanying series of experimental material models. It is informed by a series of workshops focusing on forming and casting approaches to modelling. It incorporates, synthesizes and develops the knowledge gained through collaborative site work conducted in the first two weeks of the course, and extends this into the expression of a site-specific architectural gesture that forms the basis of the design response you will develop through the course. It is supported by a narrative document that incorporates diagrams, drawings, developmental imagery and critical texts.

contentlets.description: This studio focuses on the design of adaptable, dynamic built spaces and landscapes on a dramatic Sydney foreshore site with indigenous and industrial heritage. It builds upon your work in previous design studios in the Architecture Program. You will need to bring your accumulated design knowledge to this studio in order to negotiate a major transition in terms of scale and complexity. This studio involves a major shift from a series of highly defined sites to a broader landscape, from a private program to a public program, from single buildings and landscapes to multiple buildings and landscapes, and from a series of discrete projects to one major design project.
contentlets.title: Architectural Design Studio 4

course."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ARCH1222 - Architectural History and Theory 2","description":"

An examination of key buildings and architects of Western Europe, North America, Australia, Japan and China from early modernism onwards is undertaken in this course. The selected buildings vary in scale from domestic to public, and represent an overview of key architects, collective movements and individual approaches from the mid twentieth century to the present. The selected cases are examined in terms of key ideas and problems, including: planning, cultural and intellectual contexts, formal tendencies, characters of spatial configuration, materials and responses to the physical context of a building site.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"e0406acbdba53450be4672f5f396195f","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assignment 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"50","description":"

For this assignment you are required to present an analysis of your case study building assigned to you from
the list on pages 3 and 4 of this document. First, you will produce a digital model using Sketchup and then by
creating scenes in SketchUp, present and analyse the building according to:
• Context – the immediate surrounds of the building.
• Building plan arrangement and rationale: Function, progression through spaces, etc. This should be in
the form of colour coding placed on a separate layer.
• Space: sectional arrangement and manipulation of light. Choose sections and “scenes” with shadow
settings to emphasise the space and light qualities of the building.
• Elevations: components (doors/windows) and external elements.
• Analysis of two specific aspects of the building. Select two of the following:
- Show the construction sequence of the building
- Using a series of viewpoints to show how the building is a perceptual sequence
- Demonstrate the grouping, linking and organisation of functions within the building
- Show how the physical context and/or landform has shaped or influenced the building form

Test 1 and Test 2 are designed to gauge your understanding of course lectures and readings in terms of their key points and observations. Each test will consist of 20 randomised multiple-choice questions related to the lectures and readings as listed below. You will have 15 minutes in which to complete each test. Test 1 will be held online during the Week 4 tutorial and Test 2 during the Week 9 tutorial. You will need to have access to the ARCH1222 Moodle site to undertake the tests.
Test 1
Frank Lloyd Wright lecture module
Alvar Aalto lecture module
Le Corbusier 1 lecture module
Le Corbusier 2 lecture module
Mies van der Rohe lecture module
Case Study Houses 1 lecture module
Case Study Houses 2 lecture module
Chapter 18 from Modern Architecture Since 1900

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a0406acbdba53450be4672f5f3961961","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"34406acbdba53450be4672f5f396196e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assignment 1","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

For this assignment, you are required to select a chapter from William Curtis’ book Modern Architecture Since 1900, third edition (1996). Choose three keywords from the chapter and write 500 words on each word covering: • Meaning of the word and its general usage, i.e. its meaning in a broad cultural context rather than its dictionary definition. • Architectural usage, i.e. it's meaning in the context of the chapter • Its importance in the argument put forward in the chapter • The history of the word. Not necessarily the etymology of the word, but the way it has been used and has acquired its particular associations • Buildings the word is associated with. This should include illustrations.

Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ARCH1261","attributes":[{"name":"Introductory Course","code":"introductory_course","description":"This course is usually taken in the early part of a program and may be required as a pre-requisite before taking a more advanced course."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ARCH1261 - Construction and Structures 2","description":"

This course builds on the knowledge gained in Construction and Structures 1. It extends the study of architectural materials, construction and structures through in-depth case studies where students investigate and apply knowledge of reinforced concrete and steel construction integrated with architectural design. The course explores the role of the architect and the relevance of building codes, standards and regulations applicable to medium-scale buildings. The integration of materials, structure and construction technologies with architectural design is developed through a focus on detail design and material specification.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"6850aecbdba53450be4672f5f39619a7","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Case Study Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

A building will be allocated to each student as a case study. Each student needs to investigate Gravity load-path diagrams and deflected shape under gravity load, actions and reactions of the structure under gravity load. Students are also asked to provide lateral load-path diagrams and deflected shape, actions and reactions of the structure under lateral load.                   

Written feedback in Moodle

Feedback within two weeks of submission

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"6050aecbdba53450be4672f5f39619a8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"6050aecbdba53450be4672f5f39619a9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"6050aecbdba53450be4672f5f39619aa","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"6850aecbdba53450be4672f5f39619a8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"6850aecbdba53450be4672f5f39619a9","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2850aecbdba53450be4672f5f39619ab","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Model","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

For this assessment, students are asked to fabricate a physical model of a portion of a typical structural frame either in reinforced concrete, steel or timber. The model needs to be detailed up to 1:20 scale and clearly show building parts such as each component of the flooring system, each roof component, foundation, and cross-bracing joinery.

Written feedback in Moodle

Feedback within two weeks of submission

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"6050aecbdba53450be4672f5f39619a8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"6050aecbdba53450be4672f5f39619a9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"6050aecbdba53450be4672f5f39619aa","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"6850aecbdba53450be4672f5f39619a8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"6850aecbdba53450be4672f5f39619a9","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2850aecbdba53450be4672f5f39619b2","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Construction Documentation Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

For the third assignment, students will engage with the process of developing a structural solution for a given architectural scheme. The Construction Documentation Report will be a series of A3 panels. In this submission, students will have the opportunity to design their own structure following the indication of a hypothetical architect. The report will comprise structural floorplans (1:100 scale), sections and construction detailing of a three-story building. 

Written feedback in Moodle

Feedback within two weeks of submission

course."}],"credit_points_header":"12 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ARCH1302 - Architectural Design Studio 6","description":"

The concern of this studio is with how multiple environmental, technological and social factors influence architectural thinking and production. A complex site, both in physical and cultural content, is researched and interpreted to generate an architectural strategy and its appropriate representation. As the final studio of the undergraduate degree, a single architectural proposal is developed to a detailed level of programmatic, spatial and material complexity. The proposal, or part of the proposal, will be carried through to detailed technical resolution. The final project will be assessed in relation to evidence of thought and understanding, internal coherence and imagination in the design solution, together with the employment and interface of relevant computational tools and analogical skills.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"9480a24fdba53450be4672f5f3961916","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Interim submission","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"35","description":"

Interim submission is focused on your architectural strategy in relation to site organisation, building organisation, climate response, and spatial, material, and structural qualities. The submission includes draft site plans, sections, elevations, models, and design statements.

\n

Feedback via panel discussion and analytical rubric.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"d080a24fdba53450be4672f5f3961917","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d080a24fdba53450be4672f5f3961919","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d080a24fdba53450be4672f5f396191a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d880a24fdba53450be4672f5f3961917","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d880a24fdba53450be4672f5f3961918","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"d880a24fdba53450be4672f5f3961919","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2880a24fdba53450be4672f5f396192a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Site, precedents + strategies","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

Site research and precedent study, involving measuring and translating programmatic requirements of the site into a scaled architectural approach. Students submit architectural strategies as site responses that address site organisation, building organisation, and materials and structure. Submitted as scaled diagrams and models for each strategy. Verbal presentation, with feedback via the rubric.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"d080a24fdba53450be4672f5f3961918","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d080a24fdba53450be4672f5f3961919","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d080a24fdba53450be4672f5f396191a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d880a24fdba53450be4672f5f3961917","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d880a24fdba53450be4672f5f3961918","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9880a24fdba53450be4672f5f396191b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Final Submission","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

This is your final design proposal, focused on developing and refining the construction details in relation to your architectural strategy. The submission includes site plans, sections, elevations, models, renders, and design statements.

\n

 Feedback via panel discussion and analytical rubric.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"d080a24fdba53450be4672f5f3961917","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d080a24fdba53450be4672f5f3961919","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d080a24fdba53450be4672f5f396191a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d880a24fdba53450be4672f5f3961917","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d880a24fdba53450be4672f5f3961918","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"d880a24fdba53450be4672f5f3961919","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9880a24fdba53450be4672f5f3961922","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/ARCH1302.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"","links":[]}

of Arts, Design and Architecture","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ARCH1311 - Architectural Design Studio 5","description":"

ARCH1311 (6UoC) is the fifth studio in the sequence of six Bachelor of Architectural Studies design studio courses. Students are asked to design several dwellings to accommodate a mix of household types on a single suburban lot in a middle suburb of Sydney with reference to existing models for the processes of suburban densification. The studio draws on the knowledge and skill gained in previous design studios to develop students’ skills in design generation, design development and the management of a moderate level of design complexity. It promotes coordinated relationships between the medium of architecture, patterns of human activity and elements and patterns of the site. Architectural precedents and exploratory exercises provide the foundation for the housing project. 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"b180e24fdba53450be4672f5f39619e0","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Stage 1 - Situation and site","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

The presentation and critiques of three broad options for the formal organization of the major parts in the site. The design focus is on the potential of each option to accommodate and represent the project’s human and site situations and the efficacy of broad proposals in enabling productive critiques of these potentials. The submission is individual student work. Submitted as hard copy and on Moodle. Assessment criteria:

  • The potential of each option in responding to the human and site situations.
  • The productiveness of the use of architectural precedents.
  • The extent of engagement in an explorative spirit.
  • The insightfulness and thoroughness of the critiques.

Tutor’s critiques recorded by the students, and written feedback provided in Moodle

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"f580e24fdba53450be4672f5f39619e1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f580e24fdba53450be4672f5f39619e2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f580e24fdba53450be4672f5f39619e3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"fd80e24fdba53450be4672f5f39619e0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"fd80e24fdba53450be4672f5f39619e2","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8280e24fdba53450be4672f5f39619f3","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Stage 3: A final design proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

The presentation of a final design proposal for the organization of the architecture in the site, including the identification of the key architectural strategies. The design resolution of all parts of the architecture to a level of detail that can be sufficiently presented at 1:100 is required. The submission is individual student work. Submitted as hard copy and on Moodle. Assessment criteria:

  • The responsiveness of the proposal to the human and site situations.
  • The clarity and efficacy of the key architectural strategies.
  • The productiveness of the use of architectural precedents.
  • The extent of engagement in an explorative spirit.
  • The clarity and economy of the presentation.

Written feedback in Moodle

The presentation and critique of a single proposal for the organization of the architecture in the site, including the identification of the key architectural strategies. The design of all parts of the architecture to a level of detail that can be sufficiently presented and critiqued at 1:100 is required. The submission is individual student work. Submitted as hard copy and on Moodle. Assessment criteria:

  • The responsiveness of the proposal to the human and site situations.
  • The clarity and efficacy of the key architectural strategies.
  • The productiveness of the use of architectural precedents.
  • The extent of engagement in an explorative spirit.
  • The insightfulness and thoroughness of the critique.

Tutor’s critiques recorded by the students, and written feedback provided in Moodle

course."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ARCH1322 - Architectural History and Theory 3","description":"

This course examines selected themes that embody architectural developments in Australia from the late nineteenth century to the present. These themes include nationalism and its presence in architecture and architectural discourse, the reception and interpretation of modernism, and concepts and practices of architectural regionalism. It also examines three compositional traditions – the tectonic, abstraction and figuration – in the Australian context. These themes will be explored through academic scholarship, media commentary and criticism.

course."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ARCH1331 - Architectural Fabrication","description":"

The course is designed to expand the knowledge and understanding of construction material properties and their integration with architectural forms. At first, the course will provide students with new tools and methods to understand the technical narrative behind some architectural case studies. Second, the course will support students on how to explore and develop the relationship between design and tectonics in their own projects. The course is a combination of technical analysis and workshop-based experimentation directed to understanding the hierarchy of building components and the logic behind architectural construction. Over the course, modern conceptions of architectural tectonics are presented, and physical precedents are analysed. Drawings and models at multiple scales will assist the learning experiences in this course.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"caa0228fdba53450be4672f5f3961951","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Design Strategies","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"35","description":"

Project 1 provides the opportunity to explore the potentials of the two sets of construction types – structural frame elements/systems (steel, reinforced concrete, timber) and non-load-bearing enclosing elements/systems – and the relationships between them in accommodating and representing the three human situation types. The specific context for the situation is a small multi-unit housing project. The aim is to develop a rich repertoire of design strategies that realises these potentials. To initiate your explorations, make use of architectural precedents - a list of precedents will be provided. But do not be solely reliant on precedents. And do not always start an exploration with the construction types. Try designing settings that you think address the situations without initial reference to the construction systems, and then investigate what opportunities and difficulties the settings created for the material construction. Be as explorative and playful as you can and aim to develop as broad a range of ideas as possible. No idea is too silly as a starting point for discovery. A thoughtful, rich repertoire of design strategies will provide you with a strong, inspiring foundation for Project 3 and the development of your Design Studio housing proposal.

 

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"02a0228fdba53450be4672f5f3961953","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"02a0228fdba53450be4672f5f3961954","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"02a0228fdba53450be4672f5f3961955","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0aa0228fdba53450be4672f5f3961952","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"0aa0228fdba53450be4672f5f3961953","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"0aa0228fdba53450be4672f5f3961954","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4aa0228fdba53450be4672f5f396195e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Case Study Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

This assessment requires to submit a report presenting analytical drawings exploring the relationship between design and technology for selected case studies. For each specific case study, the report must show what is the level of integration between the design principles and the technical solutions; how the technical design addressed the issues related to natural light, local climate, materials aap

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"02a0228fdba53450be4672f5f3961953","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0aa0228fdba53450be4672f5f3961952","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"0aa0228fdba53450be4672f5f3961954","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"56a0228fdba53450be4672f5f3961966","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Constructing a Setting","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

Project 2 requires the design of a setting that accommodates and represents a rich range of human situations (of the three types) likely to occur in a small multi-unit housing project - and does it very well. The design must include the surrounding settings sufficient to reveal the relationships between the settings. The structural and enclosing material elements and systems and the relationships between them must play a major role. The settings can be based on your Design Studio 5 proposal. But not necessarily, which might allow you to explore ideas not yet considered in the design studio.

contentlets.description: The course is designed to expand the knowledge and understanding of construction material properties and their integration with architectural forms. At first, the course will provide students with new tools and methods to understand the technical narrative behind some architectural case studies. Second, the course will support students on how to explore and develop the relationship between design and tectonics in their own projects. The course is a combination of technical analysis and workshop-based experimentation directed to understanding the hierarchy of building components and the logic behind architectural construction. Over the course, modern conceptions of architectural tectonics are presented, and physical precedents are analysed. Drawings and models at multiple scales will assist the learning experiences in this course.
contentlets.title: Architectural Fabrication

course."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ARCH1361 - Architectural Science and Building Environment 2","description":"

This course builds on student’s prior knowledge of architectural science and building environment with a focus on the principles and application of acoustics, lighting and comfort to achieve indoor environmental quality (IEQ) and enhanced environmental performance. The course contextualises the science of acoustics, lighting and comfort within architectural design with an emphasis on environmental data collection, analysis and application to optimise IEQ and environmental performance. The role of architectural design in mitigating indoor and outdoor thermal comfort impacts is explored through real-world case-studies and parametric modelling. The significance of daylighting and artificial lighting design in IEQ and building environmental performance is investigated through the utilisation of numerical techniques and software applications. The appraisal and design of acoustic strategies to satisfy regulatory controls and optimise IEQ is supported through the application of acoustic principles to student’s individual studio designs. At the completion of the course students will be able to identify, evaluate and apply strategies to optimise IEQ integrated with architectural design compliant with the regulatory standards applicable to environmental performance.

accepted, no further action required)

Part 1 is at the end of the multiple-choice question section.
• 1 x A4 Answers sheet for Part 2 (use answer sheet provided). The answer sheet for Part
2 is at the end of Part 2.

Assessment 2 consists of two tasks: • Task 1 – simulation of the existing lighting conditions of the meeting room in a lighting software OR calculation of the main lighting parameters using manual methods. Evaluation of the existing natural and artificial lighting conditions in the meeting room. • Task 2 – proposal of strategies to optimize the lighting conditions for the new room use (from meeting room to office space). Students are to attempt all parts and all tasks.

course."}],"credit_points_header":"12 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ARCH1481 - Critical Review of Literature","description":"

This course is a major research-based investigation into a subject related to the student’s area of specialisation. It can be seen as a building block for ARCH 1482 and ARCH1483, but it is a standalone project and yields its own outcome – a critical review of the architectural literature. This leads to a culmination of a well-informed understanding of the chosen research topic. It is expected that the critical review of the literature will offer a critical interpretation of the existing knowledge and literature. The length of the final as submitted literature review, should not exceed 8,000 words. For students undertaking a combined written and design-as-research study, the length of the written component will be a minimum of 7000 words. 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"8d01a203dbe53450be4672f5f39619b1","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Integrated Critical Review","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"60","description":"

This is a comprehensive Critical Review of the Literature, that draws on scholarly literature, relevant to the students research question, it also includes a critique of the relevant literature on the selected research methods. It involves analysis + synthesis. 

7,000 words, plus the composite bibliography.   


Review by course-coordinator and students thesis supervisor. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"8501a203dbe53450be4672f5f39619b2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"8501a203dbe53450be4672f5f39619b3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"8d01a203dbe53450be4672f5f39619b2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"8d01a203dbe53450be4672f5f39619b3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0101a203dbe53450be4672f5f39619b5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Annotated Bibliography","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

Demonstrates information literacy - the skills to appropriately locate, evaluate and use relevant information; a respect for ethical practice and social responsibility; the skills of effective communication. All students will demonstrate mastery of a recognised bibliographic citation system.

Approximately 1000 words with at least 20 scholarly texts 


Review by course-coordinator and students thesis supervisor    

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"8501a203dbe53450be4672f5f39619b2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"8501a203dbe53450be4672f5f39619b3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"8d01a203dbe53450be4672f5f39619b2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"8d01a203dbe53450be4672f5f39619b3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4501a203dbe53450be4672f5f39619bd","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Panel Review","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"10","description":"

The panel review is designed to provide an opportunity to clearly and succinctly explain the research question, it’s background and the supporting literature to a small group of staff, fellow students, and others It recognises importance of peer feedback for the critical review of the literature as a whole.

 


Peer Review and critique.    

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"8d01a203dbe53450be4672f5f39619b2","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8d01a203dbe53450be4672f5f39619ba","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Critical review of selected texts","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Demonstrates evidence that the student can evaluate the literature for what it contributes to the field of knowledge, and for its relevance to their research question.

20,000 word thesis or 7,000 words plus original design for Design thesis.  


Review by course-coordinator and students thesis supervisor.    

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"8501a203dbe53450be4672f5f39619b2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"8501a203dbe53450be4672f5f39619b3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"8d01a203dbe53450be4672f5f39619b2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"8d01a203dbe53450be4672f5f39619b3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"cd01a203dbe53450be4672f5f39619c2","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/ARCH1481.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"","links":[]}

This course is a major research-based investigation into a subject related to the student’s area of specialisation. It can be seen as a continuation of work undertaken in ARCH 1481 and ARCH 1482, but it is a standalone project and yields its own outcome – the honours thesis. This is the culmination of a well-informed understanding of the chosen research topic. It is expected that the honours thesis will offer a novel or in-depth interpretation of the existing knowledge and literature. The length of the thesis, including drawings, models and illustrations, should not exceed 20,000 words. For students undertaking a combined written and design-as-research study, the length of the written component will be a minimum of 7000 words. 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"a101e203dbe53450be4672f5f3961921","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Draft Research Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"5","description":"

Presentation and analysis of raw data.

5,000 word report.    


Structured feedback from thesis supervisor.    

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"a101e203dbe53450be4672f5f3961922","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"a101e203dbe53450be4672f5f3961923","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a901e203dbe53450be4672f5f3961921","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a901e203dbe53450be4672f5f3961922","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2501e203dbe53450be4672f5f3961924","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Panel Review","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

Each student to prepare a 10-15 minute presentation outlining their research aims and objectives, rationale, the key research methods used (and why), the research findings, evaluation and conclusion. The talk should be supported by digital images. Students undertaking design as research should show examples of their findings.

20 minute Research presentation.    


Peer Review and critique    

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a901e203dbe53450be4672f5f3961922","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2d01e203dbe53450be4672f5f396192f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Draft Thesis","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"5","description":"

To the critical review of the literature, you will add your results, discussion and conclusion chapters. In doing so it is important to identifying theoretical patterns within your field - perhaps driven by different authors’ disciplinary, geographic, ideological, or temporal biases. Different scholars, reading the same material, may legitimately come to different conclusions about its characteristics and significance; each, after all, may have a different interest and purpose. Therefore, having identified the patterns in the field, your task is to provide a cogent interpretation. You might ask: what are the core characteristics of an identified particular pattern within the field? How useful are they to my area of research? Think about evidence – internal to some of the articles, and external, as provided by other sources of knowledge – you would use to persuade a reader to accept your interpretation. 

20,000 word thesis or 7,000 words plus original design for Design thesis.    


Structured feedback from thesis supervisor    

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"a101e203dbe53450be4672f5f3961922","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"a101e203dbe53450be4672f5f3961923","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a901e203dbe53450be4672f5f3961921","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a901e203dbe53450be4672f5f3961922","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a101e203dbe53450be4672f5f396192a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Thesis","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"70","description":"

A coherent piece of research grounded in relevant theory and literature that clearly: defines the scope of the research, demonstrates a mastery of the field via a critical analysis of the literature, locates key data resources, analyse the various data sets, correlates/synthesises the various findings, evaluates the entire project for its contribution to the field, and is written in clear and succinct style. Bibliographic referencing is accurate and appropriate i.e. a UNSW recognised system such as Chicago, APA, or Harvard is used. 


Thesis examination (2 examiners unassociated with teaching and supervision)    

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"a101e203dbe53450be4672f5f3961922","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"a101e203dbe53450be4672f5f3961923","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a901e203dbe53450be4672f5f3961921","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a901e203dbe53450be4672f5f3961922","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e101e203dbe53450be4672f5f3961932","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/ARCH1483.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"","links":[]}

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ARCH2170 - Building Information Modelling","description":"

The Building Information Modelling course introduces students to understand concepts and methods of Building Information Modelling (BIM), BIM standards and BIM-based design analysis. Students generate low carbon building design through Building Information Modelling (BIM) and environmental analysis, while applying advanced skills for documentation and visualisation of buildings. Students will carry out BIM-based analysis of low carbon building design to achieve optimal design solutions, and their performance will be evaluated with respect to their progressive work developed in preparation for or during the project activities.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"c601e203dbe53450be4672f5f39619cb","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"BIM for Detailed Design ","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

Students are required to further develop a detailed BIM model based on the assignment 1, including a set of 2D drawings extracted from the detailed BIM model and appropriately annotated and structured as a documentation set, and a rendered visualisation.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ce01e203dbe53450be4672f5f39619cb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ce01e203dbe53450be4672f5f39619cc","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1e01e203dbe53450be4672f5f39619d5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"BIM-based Cost-Effective Whole-Life Carbon Analysis ","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Students are required to conduct a cost-effective whole-life carbon analysis of the detailed BIM model, including the embodied and operational carbon analysis and cost analysis based on the assignment 1 and assignment 2.      

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c601e203dbe53450be4672f5f39619cd","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4a01e203dbe53450be4672f5f39619ce","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"BIM for Conceptual Design and Energy Analysis ","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Students are required to design and model a conceptual design of a terrace house in response to a given brief and run an initial analysis of the operational energy of the conceptual BIM model to inform design changes.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"c601e203dbe53450be4672f5f39619cc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c601e203dbe53450be4672f5f39619cd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ce01e203dbe53450be4672f5f39619cc","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5201e203dbe53450be4672f5f39619d1","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/ARCH2170.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"","links":[]}

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ARCH7111 - Architectural Design Studio 1","description":"

ARCH7111, the introductory studio in the Master of Architecture Program, will help you strengthen your design research skills through a process of in-depth site analysis, research and conceptual design.


The first three weeks of the studio will focus on research (site analysis – spatial, social, economic, environmental; codes and regulations; historical changes) and problem-setting. The remainder will focus on designing potential solutions for your established problem.


As design research is an iterative process wherein potential solutions will elicit more questions and previously unseen interconnections, this structure of research followed by design is meant as a guide not an exclusive linear process. Through this inter-related process of design and research, you will develop a context-appropriate design proposal that combines the requirements of the brief with your own insights and ideas. This will allow you to begin developing the skills required to undertake your final year of studio, which will require you to write your own design brief and carry your project through the entire design process.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"63016603dbe53450be4672f5f39619f6","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment I – Site Analysis & Research – 20% - GROUP","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

This assessment is a group project. Every student is expected to work in a team to present an in-depth analysis of the site that includes insights regarding the physical environmental conditions and social, economic and political factors that have influenced the formation of the site.

 

Specifically, you must present:

  • Morphology and Site Conditions: climate and other physical factors
  • Experiential and Temporal Conditions: usage patterns, sense of place
  • Social, Political, Economic and Historical Conditions
    – diagrams, maps, photos, text
  • Key strengths, weaknesses, opportunities and threats in the site
  • Targeted design problems to be tackled for Assessment II
     

 

Required Submissions

  • In-studio presentation – 20 minutes + discussion
  • Site model, A1 presentation panel(s) and problem statement – due at
","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e3016603dbe53450be4672f5f39619f7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e3016603dbe53450be4672f5f39619f8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e3016603dbe53450be4672f5f39619f9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"eb016603dbe53450be4672f5f39619f7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b701a603dbe53450be4672f5f3961908","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment II – Preliminary Conceptual Design – 20% – INDIVIDUAL","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

This assignment is to be undertaken individually. Based on your rigorous and thoughtful site analysis and research, you will propose a preliminary conceptual design that clearly addresses the design problem.

 

Each student is expected to deliver the following:

  • Clearly articulated design problem based on Assessment I
  • Initial design proposal that clearly addresses design problem and is responsive to the site
  • Clear understanding of how different users will use the building and the site
  • Logical relationship between plans, sections and elevations
  • Legible drawings and composition that communicate design intent

 

Required Submissions composed on two to three A1 panels + models – due

  • Site plan at 1:500 (scale may differ for each stream)
  • Concept model at 1:200
  • Plans, Sections and Elevations at 1:200 or 1:100
  • Site perspectives
  • In-studio presentation – 10 minutes + discussion
","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e3016603dbe53450be4672f5f39619f7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e3016603dbe53450be4672f5f39619f8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e3016603dbe53450be4672f5f39619f9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"eb016603dbe53450be4672f5f39619f7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"eb016603dbe53450be4672f5f39619f9","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"eb016603dbe53450be4672f5f39619fb","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment III – Final Conceptual Design – 60% – INDIVIDUAL","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"60","description":"

 

This assignment is to be undertaken individually. The task is to deliver a final conceptual design that shows clear improvement from the preliminary proposal. This improvement will be evident in the depth and integration of design considerations and show how feedback was considered in making progress. The final design should contribute positively to the site and respond to the design brief.

 

Each student is expected to deliver the following:

  • Clearly articulated progress from preliminary conceptual design to final conceptual design
  • Innovative design solution that contributes positively to the site and responds to the design brief
  • Refined understanding of how different users will use the building and the site
  • Integrated relationship between plans, sections and elevations
  • Expressive and clear drawings and composition that communicate design intent

 

Required Submissions composed on three A1 panels + models – due at

  • Site plan at 1:200 or 1:500
  • Schematic model at 1:200
  • Plans, Sections and Elevations at 1:100
  • Detail plans and sections at 1:50
  • Diagrams that explain the evolution of the design from the research to the concept to the final design
  • Perspectives – one interior and one exterior that shows the context
  • In-studio presentation – 10 minutes + discussion

contentlets.description:
ARCH7111, the introductory studio in the Master of Architecture Program, will help you strengthen your design research skills through a process of in-depth site analysis, research and conceptual design.

The first three weeks of the studio will focus on research (site analysis – spatial, social, economic, environmental; codes and regulations; historical changes) and problem-setting. The remainder will focus on designing potential solutions for your established problem.

As design research is an iterative process wherein potential solutions will elicit more questions and previously unseen interconnections, this structure of research followed by design is meant as a guide not an exclusive linear process. Through this inter-related process of design and research, you will develop a context-appropriate design proposal that combines the requirements of the brief with your own insights and ideas. This will allow you to begin developing the skills required to undertake your final year of studio, which will require you to write your own design brief and carry your project through the entire design process.
contentlets.title: Architectural Design Studio 1

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ARCH7112 - Integrated Design Studio 1","description":"

ARCH7112 builds on prior knowledge gained in the Bachelor of Architecture and introductory studio to the Master of Architecture programs. ARCH7112 prepares students for their final-year Major Design Studio by providing a foundation in architectonics – the logical resolution and communication of the organising principles of architectural design expressed in the relationship between structure, materiality, form, program and space.


Students will develop the architectonics inherent to their design with a focus on precedent and assembly in order to understand and communicate how buildings and their constituent elements are organised, configured, constructed and integrated to satisfy regulatory, cultural, technical and environmental performance objectives, to represent meaning and to convey design coherence via design resolution.


Architectonics will be explored through the range of elective studio options aligned with the four major streams offered in the M. Arch degree: Architecture and High-Performance Technology, Architecture and Urban Conditions, Architecture and Housing and Architecture and Social Agency. Within the context of each stream students will develop fundamental design and documentation competencies – informed by environmental, regulatory, social, ethical and disciplinary considerations – with an emphasis on architectonics. Architectonics provides a learning framework for the development of the architectural skills, knowledge and application necessary to design, progressively resolve and document a complex project1.

Assessment 1 consists of a studio presentation and the submission of student work which documents the schematic design of the architectural proposition. 

Assessment feedback includes verbal feedback immediately after the presentation, written feedback addressing the assesssment criteria within one-week of the presentation and face-to-face feedback during the subsequent design studio.

Assessment feedback includes verbal feedback immediately after the presentation, written feedback addressing the assesssment criteria within one-week of the presentation and face-to-face feedback during the subsequent design studio.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ARCH7113 - Integrated Design Studio 2","description":"

ARCH7113 aims to prepare students for their final-year Graduation Studio and post-graduate professional work by consolidating students’ design competency with an emphasis on the principles, modes and tools of architectural documentation. Documentation is the “process of resolving, detailing and communicating an architectural project through all project stages”1. Documentation includes the use of drawings, models, specifications and schedules to communicate design intent and construction details.


Students will develop design and documentation skills through assessment tasks mapped to the Detail Design and Documentation of an architectural assembly or detail building component. Detail Design will address the integration of regulatory, structural, services, constructional and material requirements. Documentation will focus on the preparation of resolved 3D models and coordinated drawings, schedules and specifications of quality and performance standards in relation to materials, finishes, fittings and systems.


ARCH7113 logically builds on the design integration processes introduced in ARCH7112 (Integrated Design Studio 1) by reinforcing the regulatory, environmental and communication knowledge, skills and application required for the practice of architecture. Through the development of design and documentation competencies, students will build capacity to produce “fit-for-purpose” documentation at different project stages that progressively conform to accepted standards of professional architectural practice.

Assessment 3 consists of a studio presentation and the submission of student work which documents the final design resolution of the developed design and assembly detail and demonstrates advanced integration and documentation of the architectural design.

Feedback includes verbal feedback immediately after the presentation and written feedback appraising the work against the assessment criteria.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"741f6efddbae3890595850d8f496195d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"741f6efddbae3890595850d8f496195e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"781f6efddbae3890595850d8f496195c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7c1f6efddbae3890595850d8f496195d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"7c1f6efddbae3890595850d8f496195e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b81faefddbae3890595850d8f4961928","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Design Development & Integration","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Assessment 1 consists of a studio presentation and the submission of student work which documents the design development of the architectural proposition and demonstrates the preliminary integration of structure, services and environment into the architecturald design.

Feedback includes verbal feedback immediately after the presentation, written feedback appraising the work against the assessment criteria within one week of the presentation and face-to-face feedback at the subsequent studio. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"741f6efddbae3890595850d8f496195d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"781f6efddbae3890595850d8f496195c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7c1f6efddbae3890595850d8f496195d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b81faefddbae3890595850d8f4961931","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Design Resolution and Documentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Assessment 2 consists of a studio presentation and the submission of student work which documents the progressive design resolution of the developed design and assembly detail and demonstrates progressively advanced integration of structure, services and environment into the architecturald design.

Feedback includes verbal feedback immediately after the presentation, written feedback appraising the work against the assessment criteria within one week of the presentation and face-to-face feedback at the subsequent studio. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"741f6efddbae3890595850d8f496195e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7c1f6efddbae3890595850d8f496195d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"7c1f6efddbae3890595850d8f496195e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b81faefddbae3890595850d8f4961942","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/ARCH7113.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"","links":[]}

Structures","description":"

The subject builds on students’ previous experience of architectural technology by exploring some more specialised topics in structures and at the same time, looking more closely at the architectural implications of a few specific areas of construction.   We will re-visit the ideas of structural idealisation and extend its use for the conceptual design of structural systems in more significant buildings.   Structural ideas to be explored include high-rise, cantilevers, larger-span building geometry and stability.  


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"5511e603dbe53450be4672f5f396199c","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Public Building","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

This assessment will focus on the structure and detailing of a significant public building designed by students and which may link with a concurrent or previous design studio.

An assessment checklist and feedback will be provided with marked assignments.

contentlets.description: The subject builds on students’ previous experience of architectural technology by exploring some more specialised topics in structures and at the same time, looking more closely at the architectural implications of a few specific areas of construction.   We will re-visit the ideas of structural idealisation and extend its use for the conceptual design of structural systems in more significant buildings.   Structural ideas to be explored include high-rise, cantilevers, larger-span building geometry and stability.
contentlets.title: Advanced Construction and Structures

contentlets.description: Within the context of integrated design this subject explores the potentials and limitations of interdisciplinary ecological design as an approach to improving the sustainability of existing buildings and built-environments, and as a process of innovation for non-residential building design. These issues will be explored through assessment and monitoring of building performance, metabolism, comfort and services for non-residential buildings, construction ecology, and case-studies of advanced integrated design. Students will participate in a number of short design exercises responding to these issues that are designed not only to enable them in this aspect of architectural design but to develop a critical awareness of the limitations of current practice.
contentlets.title: Environment
