Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ARCH7182 - The Profession of Architecture","description":"

This course will examine a range of concepts and current issues related to professional practice and the architectural profession. As well as looking at the expectations placed on the registered architects and the ethical and legal requirements of the architect as a professional practitioner, this course will examine scales and types of architectural practice models, the agency of the architect and the role of the architect as advocate and public intellectual.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"d421ea03dbe53450be4672f5f396194b","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 2. Actions and Interactions in architectural processes","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

The aim of this assignment is to assemble narratives of the architectural process. This narrative will be articulated through a verbal presentation / video, a visual rendering / infographic or animation of the architectural process, and a written individual reflection piece.

 

In groups of two, students will undertake a mapping of a complete architectural process for:

 

  1. Small scale single residence project (project up to $2M, ‘mum and dad’ clients)
  2. Larger scale civic / public project (project up to say $50M, government or education clients)

 

In creating your mapping, you are required to delineate the typical chronology and stages of an architectural project without necessarily relying on specific time frames or showing timelines in a literal manner. Your mapping will need to examine at each stage of the architectural process the following items:

 

  • Participants
  • Stakeholders
  • Decisions
  • External processes
  • Risks
  • Opportunities
  • Time factors
  • Constraints
  • Rules – legislation as well as ‘rules of engagement’ or ‘tacit knowledge’

 

This assignment comprises 30% group work, with a 10% individual written reflection piece to be submitted alongside the main deliverables.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"1421ea03dbe53450be4672f5f396194c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1421ea03dbe53450be4672f5f396194d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"1c21ea03dbe53450be4672f5f396194c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"1c21ea03dbe53450be4672f5f396194d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1421ea03dbe53450be4672f5f396195f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3. Architect as Advocate","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

Illustrated written submission looking at notable advocacy actions and impacts on the profession.

 

Students must choose two noted advocacy actions (one historic, one recent or ongoing) initiated or led by architects (or architectural graduates and students) and review these actions against the accepted definition of architect’s agency and responsibilities (such as professional codes of conduct), as well as on accepted ethical principles. Actions can be Australian or international.

 

Students are to identify why the action was taken and to report on why the architect or architects became involved or initiated action. They will then analyse the impact of these actions on the profession, the local and wider community, legislation and government, commercial interests, etc. Both positive and negative events that occurred after the action was largely taken or completed (or if ongoing, what proposed actions are desired / called for) are to be examined and reflected upon.

 

Students will then be required to identify what they consider to be a neglected advocacy issue, and/or an ethical dilemma/s that remain/s unresolved in the architectural profession.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"1421ea03dbe53450be4672f5f396194c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1421ea03dbe53450be4672f5f396194d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"1c21ea03dbe53450be4672f5f396194c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"1c21ea03dbe53450be4672f5f396194d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2021ea03dbe53450be4672f5f3961965","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1. Local Practice Analysis","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Individual assignment – presentation and illustrated written report.

The aim of this assignment is to ask students to deep dive into how individual practices are structured and what defines and influences their rationale and philosophy, business model, staff structure, their ways of working and their built (or other) outputs. Students should use different means to procure the information about these practices including reviewing websites, media articles, books, award citations, interviews with directors, attending talks or contacting the practice directly. If you decide to contact the practice directly to ask questions, please obtain a letter of introduction from the Course Convenor first.

contentlets.description: This course will examine a range of concepts and current issues related to professional practice and the architectural profession. As well as looking at the expectations placed on the registered architects and the ethical and legal requirements of the architect as a professional practitioner, this course will examine scales and types of architectural practice models, the agency of the architect and the role of the architect as advocate and public intellectual.
contentlets.title: The Profession of Architecture

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ARCH7183 - Professional Practice 2: Projects and Practice","description":"

This course introduces students to the professional expectations and requirements of the architect practitioner. The practice of architecture and the realisation of architectural projects will be critically examined through topics that address ethical, contractual, legal, business responsibilities and project procurement.


 


The course emphasises the key roles of communication, negotiation and strategic planning in relation to the management of projects. Aspects of practice will be discussed and considered, from the fee proposal and documentation phase through to tendering, the establishment of building contracts and contract administration. Procurement and contracting methods will be presented, alongside the strategic establishment of alliances with specialty consultants, clients, stakeholders and builders.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"cd21ea03dbe53450be4672f5f39619e5","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 3","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

Assessment 03: Build the project! Tendering and Contract Administration  (40%)

This assessment will ask students to undertake tasks related to forming, issuing and assessing tenders,  letter and report writing and dealing with key Contract mechanisms. Assessment deliverables may include some or all of the following: Tender analysis and reporting, Progress Claims, Adjustment of Time claim, Variation, Architect’s Instruction, Practical Completion, Defects management, and Occupation Certificate.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"8521ea03dbe53450be4672f5f39619e7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"8521ea03dbe53450be4672f5f39619e8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"8d21ea03dbe53450be4672f5f39619e6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"8d21ea03dbe53450be4672f5f39619e7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4d21ea03dbe53450be4672f5f39619e9","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

Assessment 02: Keep the project going! Clients, Stakeholders and Project Process 40% 

This assessment will comprise both individual and group assessment components. The group assessment (15% of the subject total mark) will require students to prepare and present a mock scenario/role play to their tutorial group. The individual component (25% of the subject total mark) will involve a written back brief,  letter writing and report writing.

Students will be asked to provide concise and insightful written feedback to their peers for team and tutorial presentations. This is informal feedback which will be moderated by the course convenor and the tutors prior to a grade being determined. Students are encouraged to provide feedback to their peers as part of the CLOs and PLOs. Peer Assessment is an important skill that is used frequently in the profession. As such it is useful to commence and be involved in such a process to begin to understand how it works and be the person providing review as well as the person receiving review and comment.

Students will receive brief verbal feedback when they present a teamwork or tutorial activity. Written feedback will be provided within 2 weeks of submissions.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"8521ea03dbe53450be4672f5f39619e7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"8d21ea03dbe53450be4672f5f39619e6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"8d21ea03dbe53450be4672f5f39619e7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"c121ea03dbe53450be4672f5f39619f3","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 1","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Assessment 01: Win the Project! Fee Letter and Client Architect Agreement 

This assessment will ask students to prepare a fee letter with short summary brief and actual fees / fee method nominated, and a client architect agreement that reflects the offer in the fee letter. This will be based on a hypothetical small scale public project (<$5M) that also forms the basis of Assignments 02 and 03.


Students will be asked to provide concise and insightful written feedback to their peers for team and tutorial presentations. This is informal feedback which will be moderated by the course convenor and the tutors prior to a grade being determined. Students are encouraged to provide feedback to their peers as part of the CLOs and PLOs. Peer Assessment is an important skill that is used frequently in the profession. As such it is useful to commence and be involved in such a process to begin to understand how it works and be the person providing review as well as the person receiving review and comment.

Students will receive brief verbal feedback when they present a teamwork or tutorial activity. Written feedback will be provided within 2 weeks of submissions.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ARCH7201 - Research Studio","description":"

The Graduation Studio in the Masters of Architecture Program is run over two terms; the first term is the Research Studio where students develop the intellectual inquiry and research that defines their project, along with their initial architectural proposals. The second term accommodates the Major Design Studio where students develop this into a comprehensively resolved architecture project.


In the Research Studio students select from a series of design elective options each offering a specific architectural proposition allied with the program streams, namely: Architecture + High Performance Technology, Architecture + Housing, Architecture + Social Agency, and Architecture + Urban Conditions. Emphasis is placed on theoretical research, exploration, speculation and analysis aimed at a conscious framing of an architectural position. An ability to select appropriate architectural strategies, representation methods, computational instruments and technical solutions will be pursued. Studio-based programs guide the definition of a conceptual architectural proposal that describes the parameters and architectural ambitions of individual projects. The proposal will be developed to a comprehensive level of resolution in ARCH7202: Major Design Studio.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"21212e03dbe53450be4672f5f3961980","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1 – Analytics: Site & Precedent (Group)","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

This phase is an intensive group research and analysis exercise focusing on studio questions, site, thematic and precedent. The process and product of this phase will constitute the analytics that are then used to develop the research focus and architectural position for your project. Work will be undertaken in groups of 4 -6 students, with each group focusing on in-depth analysis of different aspects of the site and a detailed precedent study of exemplar buildings related to the studio premise.

Analysis and learnings from site and precedent studies will be communicated through drawings and physical models as appropriate. It will be expected that this gathering will be extensive and its assemblage and presentation rigorous and professional. All drawings / information will be collated in an exhibition – a shared resource for all to use.

Assessment type: Exhibition, presentation and digital submission to Moodle (group)

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"21212e03dbe53450be4672f5f3961982","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e5212e03dbe53450be4672f5f3961984","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3 - Project Brief and Conceptual Design (Individual)","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"60","description":"

This phase is an individual enquiry focusing on the development of a detailed brief and conceptual design for your selected building/s, based on the analysis, research and principles established by the previous stages.

The conceptual design for your project should focus on the key aspects and scales important to your studio and Research Question but could include the definition of program activities and distribution, circulation, site connectivity, sustainability strategies, material and spatial strategies and structural strategies. However, it is important your work at this stage demonstrates your thinking across multiple scales; urban, building and tectonic. Plans, sections, axonometric drawings, models and perspectives should be developed that adequately describe the key components of the scheme and describe the character and quality of built form.

Assessment type: presentation and digital submission to Moodle (individual)

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"21212e03dbe53450be4672f5f3961981","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"29212e03dbe53450be4672f5f3961980","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"29212e03dbe53450be4672f5f3961981","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"29212e03dbe53450be4672f5f3961982","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e9212e03dbe53450be4672f5f396198b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2 - Research Question and Initial Design Strategies (Individual)","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

This phase is an individual enquiry focusing on the development of a conceptual framework for your project. This involves extending the group studies with thematic-based research and developing a research question for your individual project. The Research Question is a clear statement of the focus of your project, identifying the unique scope of your investigation within the overarching studio brief – what will your project be about? What makes your project unique? Studio Leaders have identified a set of Studio Questions privileging the direction of design research project. With the first stage of investigation, in Assessment 2, you are encouraged to develop your research question from a mixture of site, precedent and thematic research accentuated by your own personal interests; whether  performative,  contextual,  social,  political,  economic, philosophical,  geographical,  technical  or typological, noting that architecture is generated by exposing potentially conflicting issues into a balanced holistic design.

For the design strategies, you will be required to explore, critique and experiment in developing a proposition that relates to your studio and research question. Depending on your studio, you may choose to explore different parameters or scales.

Assessment type: presentation and digital submission to Moodle (individual)

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ARCH7202 - Major Design Studio","description":"

The Graduation Studio in the Masters of Architecture Program is run over two terms; the first term is the Research Studio where students develop the intellectual inquiry and research that defines their project, along with their initial architectural proposals. The second term accommodates the Major Design Studio where students develop this into a comprehensively resolved architecture project.


In the Major Design Studio, students continue in their previous studio group to create rigorous and compelling architecture. Each studio explicitly supports the detailed design development of individual architectural proposals as realised through appropriate modes of architectural representation. Emphasis is placed on development of the architectural proposition through critique and testing. The developed design will reach an ambitious level of programmatic, spatial, material, environmental and technological integration and resolution, with an ambitious and imaginative level of experimentation. Students will evaluate and develop architectural representation styles and techniques to establish the most effective methods to communicate their work. Presentation to peers, eminent critics and practitioners occurs through studio reviews and a public graduation exhibition.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"8e216e03dbe53450be4672f5f396190a","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3 - Final Design","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"60","description":"

Final Design (50%) and presentation models / hard materials outputs (10%).

Assessment 3 takes the form of a studio presentation which presents the Final Design for your selected building/s. This will be the completion of 9-months of research, testing, design development and graphical communication.

Based on the Developed Design undertaken in Assessment 2, a complete set of drawings and models of your scheme is required to articulate the formal configuration in relation to the program and inhabitation, as well as the structural, constructional, environmental and tectonic resolution. Particular focus at this stage will be given to the creativity and craft of final graphical and model representations.

Students will receive feedback for their work in many ways:
• Verbal feedback weekly at tutorials. In the first four weeks students will receive tutorials
in groups. Thereafter tutorials will be individual. It is up to students to accurately record
verbal feedback either by writing notes, or audio recording (please ask permission from
your tutors before audio recording)
• Written feedback from assessments, including a suggestion of performance against the
assessment criteria
• Peer and guest review feedback from individual presentations.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"c2216e03dbe53450be4672f5f396190c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c2216e03dbe53450be4672f5f396190e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ca216e03dbe53450be4672f5f396190b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"ca216e03dbe53450be4672f5f396190c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1a216e03dbe53450be4672f5f396191f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2 - Detailed Design","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Based on the Initial Design undertaken in Assessment 1, a developed set of drawings and models of your scheme is required to articulate the formal configuration in relation to the program and inhabitation, as well as the structural, constructional, tectonic and environmental integration. This stage requires you to develop your project to a technical level of detail, including tectonic development up to a minimum of 1:50 (and possibly including 1:20/1:10 and 1:5 details). To support this, this phase of the project will be supplemented by dedicated structural, technological and environmental tutorials.

Students will receive feedback for their work in many ways:
• Verbal feedback weekly at tutorials. In the first four weeks students will receive tutorials
in groups. Thereafter tutorials will be individual. It is up to students to accurately record
verbal feedback either by writing notes, or audio recording (please ask permission from
your tutors before audio recording)
• Written feedback from assessments, including a suggestion of performance against the
assessment criteria
• Peer and guest review feedback from individual presentations.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"c2216e03dbe53450be4672f5f396190c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c2216e03dbe53450be4672f5f396190d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c2216e03dbe53450be4672f5f396190e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ca216e03dbe53450be4672f5f396190b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"ca216e03dbe53450be4672f5f396190c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ca216e03dbe53450be4672f5f396190d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1e216e03dbe53450be4672f5f3961917","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1 - Draft Design","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Assessment 1 takes the form of a studio presentation and physical submission of work which documents the Initial Design for your selected building/s.

Based on the research and initial design testing undertaken in ARCH7201 in Term 1, key ideas are developed through draft design, including program, site and context, 2-dimentional and/or 3-dimentional planning strategies, formal configuration and the initial technological and technical implications on design including structural, construction and environment. 

Students will receive feedback for their work in many ways:
• Verbal feedback weekly at tutorials. In the first four weeks students will receive tutorials
in groups. Thereafter tutorials will be individual. It is up to students to accurately record
verbal feedback either by writing notes, or audio recording (please ask permission from
your tutors before audio recording)
• Written feedback from assessments, including a suggestion of performance against the
assessment criteria
• Peer and guest review feedback from individual presentations.

contentlets.description:
The Graduation Studio in the Masters of Architecture Program is run over two terms; the first term is the Research Studio where students develop the intellectual inquiry and research that defines their project, along with their initial architectural proposals. The second term accommodates the Major Design Studio where students develop this into a comprehensively resolved architecture project.

In the Major Design Studio, students continue in their previous studio group to create rigorous and compelling architecture. Each studio explicitly supports the detailed design development of individual architectural proposals as realised through appropriate modes of architectural representation. Emphasis is placed on development of the architectural proposition through critique and testing. The developed design will reach an ambitious level of programmatic, spatial, material, environmental and technological integration and resolution, with an ambitious and imaginative level of experimentation. Students will evaluate and develop architectural representation styles and techniques to establish the most effective methods to communicate their work. Presentation to peers, eminent critics and practitioners occurs through studio reviews and a public graduation exhibition.
contentlets.title: Major Design Studio

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ARCH7211 - Graduation Research Studio","description":"

The Graduation Studio in the Masters of Architecture Program is run over two terms; the first term is the
Research Studio where students develop the intellectual inquiry and research that defines their project, along
with their initial architectural proposals. The second term accommodates the Major Design Studio where
students develop this into a comprehensively resolved architecture project.

In the Research Studio students select from a series of design elective options each offering a specific
architectural proposition allied with the program streams, namely: Architecture + High Performance
Technology, Architecture + Housing, Architecture + Social Agency, and Architecture + Urban Conditions.
Emphasis is placed on theoretical research, exploration, speculation and analysis aimed at a conscious
framing of an architectural position. An ability to select appropriate architectural strategies, representation
methods, computational instruments and technical solutions will be pursued. Studio-based programs guide
the definition of a conceptual architectural proposal that describes the parameters and architectural ambitions
of individual projects. The proposal will be developed to a comprehensive level of resolution in ARCH7202:
Major Design Studio.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"c721ae03dbe53450be4672f5f3961932","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2: Research Question and Initial Design Strategies (Individual)","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

This phase is an individual enquiry focusing on the development of a conceptual framework for your project. This involves extending the group studies with thematic-based research and developing a research question for your individual project. The Research Question is a clear statement of the focus of your project, identifying the unique scope of your investigation within the overarching studio brief – what will your project be about? What makes your project unique? Studio Leaders have identified a set of Studio Questions privileging the direction of design research project. With the first stage of investigation, in Assessment 2, you are encouraged to develop your research question from a mixture of site, precedent and thematic research accentuated by your own personal interests; whether  performative,  contextual,  social,  political,  economic, philosophical,  geographical,  technical  or typological, noting that architecture is generated by exposing potentially conflicting issues into a balanced holistic design.

For the design strategies, you will be required to explore, critique and experiment in developing a proposition that relates to your studio and research question. Depending on your studio, you may choose to explore different parameters or scales.

Assessment type: presentation and digital submission to Moodle (individual)

 

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"c721ae03dbe53450be4672f5f3961933","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"c721ae03dbe53450be4672f5f3961934","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"c721ae03dbe53450be4672f5f3961935","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1721ae03dbe53450be4672f5f396193f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Analytics – Site and Precedent (Group)","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

The phase is an intensive group research and analysis exercise focusing on studio questions, site, thematic and precedent. The process and product of this phase will constitute the analytics that are then used to develop the research focus and architectural position for your project. Work will be undertaken in groups of 4 -6 students, with each group focusing on in-depth analysis of different aspects of the site and a detailed precedent study of exemplar buildings related to the studio premise.

Analysis and learnings from site and precedent studies will be communicated through drawings and physical models as appropriate. It will be expected that this gathering will be extensive and its assemblage and presentation rigorous and professional. All drawings / information will be collated in an exhibition – a shared resource for all to use.

Assessment type: Exhibition, presentation and digital submission to Moodle (group)

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"cf21ae03dbe53450be4672f5f3961933","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1f21ae03dbe53450be4672f5f396193c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3: Project Brief and Conceptual Design (Individual)","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"60","description":"

This phase is an individual enquiry focusing on the development of a detailed brief and conceptual design for your selected building/s, based on the analysis, research and principles established by the previous stages.

The conceptual design for your project should focus on the key aspects and scales important to your studio and Research Question but could include the definition of program activities and distribution, circulation, site connectivity, sustainability strategies, material and spatial strategies and structural strategies. However, it is important your work at this stage demonstrates your thinking across multiple scales; urban, building and tectonic. Plans, sections, axonometric drawings, models and perspectives should be developed that adequately describe the key components of the scheme and describe the character and quality of built form.

Assessment type: presentation and digital submission to Moodle (individual)

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ARCH7212 - Graduation Research Studio","description":"

The Graduation Studio in the Masters of Architecture Program is run over two terms; the first term is the
Research Studio where students develop the intellectual inquiry and research that defines their project, along
with their initial architectural proposals. The second term accommodates the Major Design Studio where
students develop this into a comprehensively resolved architecture project.

In the Research Studio students select from a series of design elective options each offering a specific
architectural proposition allied with the program streams, namely: Architecture + High Performance
Technology, Architecture + Housing, Architecture + Social Agency, and Architecture + Urban Conditions.
Emphasis is placed on theoretical research, exploration, speculation and analysis aimed at a conscious
framing of an architectural position. An ability to select appropriate architectural strategies, representation
methods, computational instruments and technical solutions will be pursued. Studio-based programs guide
the definition of a conceptual architectural proposal that describes the parameters and architectural ambitions
of individual projects. The proposal will be developed to a comprehensive level of resolution in ARCH7202:
Major Design Studio.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"fb21ae03dbe53450be4672f5f39619b2","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1 - Analytics: Site and Precedent (Group)","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

This phase is an intensive group research and analysis exercise focusing on studio questions, site, thematic and precedent. The process and product of this phase will constitute the analytics that are then used to develop the research focus and architectural position for your project. Work will be undertaken in groups of 4 -6 students, with each group focusing on in-depth analysis of different aspects of the site and a detailed precedent study of exemplar buildings related to the studio premise.

Analysis and learnings from site and precedent studies will be communicated through drawings and physical models as appropriate. It will be expected that this gathering will be extensive and its assemblage and presentation rigorous and professional. All drawings / information will be collated in an exhibition – a shared resource for all to use.

Assessment type: Exhibition, presentation and digital submission to Moodle (group)

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"bb21ae03dbe53450be4672f5f39619b5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4031ae03dbe53450be4672f5f39619c2","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2 - Research Question and Initial Design Strategies (Individual)","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

This phase is an individual enquiry focusing on the development of a conceptual framework for your project. This involves extending the group studies with thematic-based research and developing a research question for your individual project. The Research Question is a clear statement of the focus of your project, identifying the unique scope of your investigation within the overarching studio brief – what will your project be about? What makes your project unique? Studio Leaders have identified a set of Studio Questions privileging the direction of design research project. With the first stage of investigation, in Assessment 2, you are encouraged to develop your research question from a mixture of site, precedent and thematic research accentuated by your own personal interests; whether  performative,  contextual,  social,  political,  economic, philosophical,  geographical,  technical  or typological, noting that architecture is generated by exposing potentially conflicting issues into a balanced holistic design.

For the design strategies, you will be required to explore, critique and experiment in developing a proposition that relates to your studio and research question. Depending on your studio, you may choose to explore different parameters or scales.

Assessment type: presentation and digital submission to Moodle (individual)

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"b321ae03dbe53450be4672f5f39619b4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"b321ae03dbe53450be4672f5f39619b5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"b321ae03dbe53450be4672f5f39619b6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"bb21ae03dbe53450be4672f5f39619b3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7b21ae03dbe53450be4672f5f39619b7","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3: Project Brief and Conceptual Design (Individual)","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"60","description":"

This phase is an individual enquiry focusing on the development of a detailed brief and conceptual design for your selected building/s, based on the analysis, research and principles established by the previous stages.

The conceptual design for your project should focus on the key aspects and scales important to your studio and Research Question but could include the definition of program activities and distribution, circulation, site connectivity, sustainability strategies, material and spatial strategies and structural strategies. However, it is important your work at this stage demonstrates your thinking across multiple scales; urban, building and tectonic. Plans, sections, axonometric drawings, models and perspectives should be developed that adequately describe the key components of the scheme and describe the character and quality of built form.

Assessment type: presentation and digital submission to Moodle (individual)

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ARCH7213 - Performance over Time of Building Systems","description":"

In this course, you will be introduced to the analysis of the users’ needs related to the architectural space, translating these into performance-based requirements and specifications to prevent building defects and durability issues. You will investigate the durability of building envelope components and the possible design countermeasures to the most common defects due to errors in conception, construction, or maintenance. Your detailed technological design will be informed by software simulations of the hygrothermal performance of building components. Finally, you will orient your work in relation to the regulatory framework – including the National Construction Code and technical standards (e.g., AS/NZS or ISO standards) – to develop specifications, and verify the delivered performance and building quality.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"70ca7ddedb167850595850d8f496195d","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"From technical design brief to performance verification","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Assignment 3 (Groups of three students - 30%). Technical design brief and performance verification. You produce a consolidated report on the findings presented in Assignment 1 and Assignment 2, focusing on how to prevent the issues from occurring, and how to implement the dissemination of this information in your firm. You consider the users’ needs and then of the standards and technical information, and development of specifications for all the most relevant performance criteria concerning a selected building component.

Feedback process: written feedback to the group in Moodle with quantitative assessment, justification and recommendations to improve.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"38ca7ddedb167850595850d8f496195f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3cca7ddedb167850595850d8f496195e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"74ca7ddedb167850595850d8f4961966","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Hygrothermal performance","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"35","description":"

Assignment 1 (Individual - 35%). Hygrothermal performance. Analysis of the hygrothermal performance of building envelope components and moisture-related risks, and material and design options to overcome the issue.

Feedback process: written feedback in Moodle with quantitative assessment, justification and recommendations to improve.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"30ca7ddedb167850595850d8f4961960","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3cca7ddedb167850595850d8f496195e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8dca7ddedb167850595850d8f4961969","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Building Pathology and Durability","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"35","description":"

Assignment 2 (Individual - 35%). Building Pathology and Durability. Analysis of the performance over time of a selected building envelope component (i.e., most common failure modes and durability issues), with design, construction and/or maintenance countermeasures.

Feedback process: written feedback in Moodle with quantitative assessment, justification and recommendations to improve.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"30ca7ddedb167850595850d8f4961960","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3cca7ddedb167850595850d8f496195e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b8ca7ddedb167850595850d8f4961961","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/ARCH7213.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"","links":[]}

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ARCH7214 - Architecture and Politics","description":"

The course introduces students to the philosophies that have both generated architectural designs since the early 20th century, as well as those which allowed criticism of prevailing work. These will be placed in the context of wider social, political and economic concerns that marked the 20th Century, and the start of the 21st. Lectures will introduce the main trends of thought of the period, which include evolutionism, Marxism, existentialism, structuralism and environmentalism. Case studies of the works of key architectural writers are undertaken in seminars. The course will enable students to categorize architectural works from the period according to the philosophy or ideas they embody, and to critically appreciate the strengths and limitations of those ideas.


 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"aa316243dbe53450be4672f5f39619c8","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Participation","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

Attendance record, response to specific questions on material in class.

A composite mark is awarded for attendance and reading preparation as evidenced in class discussion.


Comments added to individual essay feedback.    

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e2316243dbe53450be4672f5f39619ca","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e2316243dbe53450be4672f5f39619cb","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"62316243dbe53450be4672f5f39619d1","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2 - Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

An individual essay of 2500 (strictly +/- 10%) words based on one of the readings. This will elaborate on the themes of the reading, and relate them to the broader body of work of the writer or the broader debate they are contributing to. Essays should be structured as follows:
Introduction. Place the reading in context. Where does it fit into the writer’s body of work?
Details of the reading. Summarise the reading, highlighting its key themes and points. Explain these clearly, and link them to other writings and buildings (by other authors) of the time.
Relate them to architectural works. Show how the readings are relevant to discussions of the time about appropriate forms of architecture or movements/intentions in architecture of the period.
Conclusion. State your conclusions as developed through the essay. This can be in the form of a critique of the piece, perhaps with the benefit of historical hindsight, or it can be in the form of an evaluation of the influence of the writer on the architecture of their time or that which came after.
Essays will be marked on:
Clarity of structure (as laid out above).
Language – accurate usage and clear expression and proofreading.
Reference – consistency of your referencing system. A suggested system is presented below.
The exam week will be devoted to developing these essay themes. An outline of your topic must be emailed to the lecturer before you commence the final write-up.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e2316243dbe53450be4672f5f39619ca","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e2316243dbe53450be4672f5f39619cb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ea316243dbe53450be4672f5f39619ca","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"66316243dbe53450be4672f5f39619cc","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1 - Group Presentation of Selected Reading","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Group exercise
Each week a group will be asked to prepare one reading in the following form:
The group will formulate a number of questions that arise out of the reading, and then answer those questions. It is anticipated that the number of questions will be 4-6, depending on the nature of the reading. Additional questions that the group prepared can be addressed to the lecturer and class. Class members not presenting are also asked to formulate questions, which can then form the basis for discussion of the texts. The question/answer session will follow the lecture on the readings.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ARCH7215 - Advanced Themes in Australian Architecture","description":"

This course offers an in-depth study of Australian architecture through the work of selected architects and themes. It will explore the complexity of ideas and philosophies that have influenced and shaped the work of some of Australia's leading architectural practitioners both historically and in the present. The course consists of lectures and tutorial discussions.


 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"cd416643dbe53450be4672f5f3961997","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Test","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

The Test consists of 20 multiple choice questions related to the weekly class readings for this course.
The Test is designed to gauge student understanding of these readings in terms of both facts and arguments.

Test results are released via the course Moodle site. General feedback is given in class time.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"09416643dbe53450be4672f5f396199a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"05416643dbe53450be4672f5f396199f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 2 (2000-word essay)","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"45","description":"

Requirement: This assignment (which involves the production of a 2000-word essay) is devoted to the study of recent and contemporary architecture in Australia. Buildings will be investigated through the consideration of themes pertinent to understanding contemporary developments.

The following criteria is used to assess assignments:
• Response to assignment brief and requirements
• Level of care in written expression
• Clarity, thoroughness and correctness of referencing
• Quality of presentation

Individual feedback is provided through a feedback sheet. General feedback is presented in class time.

Requirement: In his entry on postmodernism within The Encyclopedia of Australian Architecture Conrad Hamann describes the different ways post-modern thinking manifested itself in architecture in Australia. He identifies architects and architectural practices that responded positively to post-modern ideas and concerns. For this assignment you are required to examine how the work of two architects or architectural practices mentioned in Hamann’s entry expressed (and continues to express, as the case may be) post-modern concerns.

The following criteria is used to assess assignments:
• Response to assignment brief and requirements
• Level of care in written expression
• Clarity, thoroughness and correctness of referencing
• Quality of presentation

Individual feedback is provided through a feedback sheet. General feedback is presented in class time.

contentlets.description: This course offers an in-depth study of Australian architecture through the work of selected architects and themes. It will explore the complexity of ideas and philosophies that have influenced and shaped the work of some of Australia's leading architectural practitioners both historically and in the present. The course consists of lectures and tutorial discussions.
contentlets.title: Advanced Themes in Australian Architecture

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ARCH7216 - Designing Diversity: Architecture and Urbanism in a Multicultural Context","description":"

This course considers the relationships between built environment, culture and society. It aims to present social and cultural processes and modes of engagement as vital in the shaping of urban space and a sense of place. Building on interpretative techniques and visual methodologies of sociology, cultural studies and/or anthropology, students will develop their own understandings of the interconnections between the built fabric, the individuals and communities for whom cities are created.  The course will provide students with the skills to interpret relationships between urban spaces and specific cultural practices and patterns of habitation. Sydney provides the primary site for student projects; its multicultural character offers a rich context for interrogating the relationship between architecture and culture. The course considers a number of distinct types of spaces, such as migrant and minority groups’ religious and community spaces, for their spatial representation of beliefs and practices. Diverse community and public spaces as well as places of consumption will be studied for their capacity to engage with popular and daily aspects of culture as well as for their ability to negotiate the representation of dominant and marginal groups. 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"df412a43dbe53450be4672f5f396197e","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group Submission Maps-Text-Representation","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Groups are to create a series of maps of the selected suburb documenting relationships and networks between specific types of buildings or landmarks. These maps are to communicate new narratives discovered through research and site visits. Students will be assessed on the comprehensiveness of their historical and social research, the clarity and completeness of the documentation, and the originality and insightfulness of the relationships and networks the group draws from their analysis.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"13412a43dbe53450be4672f5f3961981","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"13412a43dbe53450be4672f5f3961983","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1b412a43dbe53450be4672f5f3961981","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"1b412a43dbe53450be4672f5f3961982","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"13412a43dbe53450be4672f5f396198a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Individual Submission Maps-Text-Representation","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

Students are to select one building located within their group suburb to investigate. Students are to explore the social/cultural/historical significance of the selected building, and the various narratives and counternarratives of the building through research and site visits.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"13412a43dbe53450be4672f5f3961981","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"13412a43dbe53450be4672f5f3961983","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1b412a43dbe53450be4672f5f3961981","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"1b412a43dbe53450be4672f5f3961982","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"93412a43dbe53450be4672f5f3961984","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Video Submission A Story of a Suburb + Reflection","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Student will hone in on a particular aspect or narrative of their suburb or selected building and its socio-cultural reality, tying together their former research and the most interesting facets they have uncovered through the medium of video.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"13412a43dbe53450be4672f5f3961981","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"13412a43dbe53450be4672f5f3961982","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"13412a43dbe53450be4672f5f3961983","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"1b412a43dbe53450be4672f5f3961980","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1b412a43dbe53450be4672f5f3961981","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"1b412a43dbe53450be4672f5f3961982","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"ab412a43dbe53450be4672f5f396198f","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/ARCH7216.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"","links":[]}

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ARCH7218 - Urban Climate Change - Mitigation and Adaptation in the Urban Built Environment","description":"

This course will focus on the urban climate problems and the relevant mitigation and adaptation design techniques and technologies to counterbalance the temperature increase in the urban built environment. The first part of the course, will explore the major issues around the climate of cities, will offer advanced knowledge on the interaction between the urban climate, buildings, and open spaces, and will analyze the main impact of local climate change on energy, indoor and outdoor thermal comfort, health, and economy. The second part of the course will explore, analyze, and present in detail the major mitigation and adaptation design techniques and technologies to counterbalance the urban temperature increase. It will investigate and present issues related to the appropriate use of materials in cities, new advanced and cutting edge materials for open spaces and buildings, heat dissipation and amortization technologies for buildings and open spaces based on the use of low temperature environmental sinks, smart energy and environmental management technologies for cities, Anthropogenic heat avoidance technologies and all aspects related to the proper use of urban greenery in the urban built environment. Examples from successful real case studies will be presented. Modelling techniques (i.e. ENVI-met) to simulate the thermal characteristics of cities and evaluate the impact of the main mitigation technologies will be presented, analyzed, and used by the students.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"7951ea43dbe53450be4672f5f39619b1","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final submission, report and simulations outcome","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"60","description":"

A case study on the rehabilitation of urban buildings and open spaces to counterbalance the impacts of local climate change. Students will perform microclimate simulations and apply mitigation technologies, they interpret the results and submit the outcome. Students will require to also present orally as part of the final assessment.

Peer critique and written feedback

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"7151ea43dbe53450be4672f5f39619c0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"7151ea43dbe53450be4672f5f39619c1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"7951ea43dbe53450be4672f5f39619bf","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7951ea43dbe53450be4672f5f39619c0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7551ea43dbe53450be4672f5f39619c9","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Preliminary analysis of site and climate","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

Students will perform an analysis of the existing condition in relation to the site and climate. Students will submit their analysis in a report format. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"7151ea43dbe53450be4672f5f39619c1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7951ea43dbe53450be4672f5f39619c0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7d51ea43dbe53450be4672f5f39619c5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"A report of field monitoring and measurement","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will perform field measurement at UNSW campus and report their findings and results of monitoring. Students will be graded individually on a group assessment in which each student will undertake different components of the project.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ARCH7219 - Graduation Exhibition Design","description":"

This course enables students to engage in collaborative activities to research, design, prepare and produce
a high profile public exhibition of graduating architecture student work.
The course aims to introduce students to the ideas and practices of curating and exhibiting architecture. A
theoretical component will contextualise the practice of exhibiting architecture and a research assignment
will provide exposure to numerous case studies and international precedents.
Working in small groups, students will have the opportunity to produce the exhibition, demonstrating design
skills and knowledge of spatial narrative, and modular detailing. Students will extend their research, design
and implementation skills, responding to the practical and technical limitations of time, location, budget and
resources.

contentlets.description:
This course enables students to engage in collaborative activities to research, design, prepare and produce
a high profile public exhibition of graduating architecture student work.
The course aims to introduce students to the ideas and practices of curating and exhibiting architecture. A
theoretical component will contextualise the practice of exhibiting architecture and a research assignment
will provide exposure to numerous case studies and international precedents.
Working in small groups, students will have the opportunity to produce the exhibition, demonstrating design
skills and knowledge of spatial narrative, and modular detailing. Students will extend their research, design
and implementation skills, responding to the practical and technical limitations of time, location, budget and
resources.

of Arts, Design and Architecture","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ARCH7220 - Architecture and Urbanism in Asia","description":"

This course introduces you to the multiplicity and complexity of Asia through investigations of Asian cities and architecture. You will examine canonical monuments as well as everyday vernacular places and interstitial spaces. As you explore cities in South, Southeast and East Asia at multiple scales, you will investigate the following themes: the concept of Asia, idealised cities and architecture, globalising forces influencing Asian architecture and urbanism, and contestations over modernism.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"1324c112db527850595850d8f496190e","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Short essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

Students will respond to two of three provided essay questions.  Each essay will be approximately 1000 words (+/- 10%). Feedback via comments in Turnitin.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"1324c112db527850595850d8f4961910","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"1324c112db527850595850d8f4961911","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1724c112db527850595850d8f496190f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"1b24c112db527850595850d8f4961910","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2724c112db527850595850d8f496191a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Learning portfolio","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

For the Learning Portfolio you will curate the work you generate in the tutorial and discussion activities and write short reflections of no more than 1,000 words total.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"1324c112db527850595850d8f4961910","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"1324c112db527850595850d8f4961911","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1724c112db527850595850d8f496190f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"1b24c112db527850595850d8f4961910","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5724c112db527850595850d8f4961913","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Lead one discussion","assessment_type":{"label":"Tutorial work","value":"tutorial_work"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will work in teams to prepare study sheets that include all mandatory and recommended reading and documentaries. Each required text or video should have an  abstract of 100 to 150 words plus an outline of the key points. The team will then present their synthesis using slides (30 to 40 minutes total) and lead a discussion (15 to 20 minutes) based on their prepared material. Verbal discussion and analytical rubric as feedback.

\n

This course focuses on elements of architectural design, design thinking and representational strategies. It will review and explore these ideas from the viewpoint of acquired knowledge and skills from undergraduate studies.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"0d716683dbe53450be4672f5f396191e","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"1b. Case study (group)","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Undertaken in groups of 4-5 students and a continuation of Project 1a. There are two steps in this project:  1. Research of 2 selected architectural precedents based on each design concept presented in Project 1a.

2. Explore the 4 case studies (2 design concepts x 2 case studies) and reveal one aspect of the relationships between design concepts and design strategies.

Project 3: Tutorial exercises

A series of exercises undertaken during the tutorial time, based upon the ideas presented in the lectures and supporting the current project tasks.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"05716683dbe53450be4672f5f396191f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"05716683dbe53450be4672f5f3961920","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0d716683dbe53450be4672f5f396191f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0d716683dbe53450be4672f5f3961920","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"09716683dbe53450be4672f5f3961925","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"2. Project design and analysis","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

Project 2: Project design and analysis

Undertaken as individual student work. There are two steps in this project:

1. The design of a small architectural intevertion that re-interprets the relationship between a design concept and design strategie explored in Project 1b, in the context of a changed program and site.

2. An analysis of your design, communicating your interpretation of the aspect relating the specific design concepts and the design strategies to one another.

Research (group)","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

Project 1a: Research

Undertaken in groups of 4-5 students. Research of 4-5 keywords investigating their history and theory and identifying two existing processes of design thinking that bring them together as design concepts.

contentlets.description: This course focuses on elements of architectural design, design thinking and representational strategies. It will review and explore these ideas from the viewpoint of acquired knowledge and skills from undergraduate studies.
contentlets.title: Elements of Architectural Design

Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"ARCH7227","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ARCH7227 - A History of Housing","description":"

Rich housing types embody all manner of forms, customs and styles, which vary in cultures in pre-modern times, and are likely to vary even in individuals in our time. But when viewed as a formal configuration, beyond shapes and dimensions, housing throughout human history, surprisingly, can be classified into a few limited patterns. They include, specifically, the courtyard pattern, the inter-connected room matrix pattern, and the pattern of terminal rooms opening to a common corridor. This course examines the human relations that are not only cemented but also animated through the human occupation of these patterns, which leads to an understanding of modern housing against such historical background.


This course introduces to students various interpretive and analytical approaches drawn from the humanist tradition and historical studies, as well as nineteenth-century development of the Ecole des Beaux-Arts and modern anthropology, which will enable them to gain an overview of housing history in both Europe and Asia from antiquity to the present. By offering focused and in-depth studies of selected themes and cases in housing history, this course uses the house as a vehicle to enable students to reflect on, and enhance, their prior studies of architectural history and housing design.

contentlets.description:
Rich housing types embody all manner of forms, customs and styles, which vary in cultures in pre-modern times, and are likely to vary even in individuals in our time. But when viewed as a formal configuration, beyond shapes and dimensions, housing throughout human history, surprisingly, can be classified into a few limited patterns. They include, specifically, the courtyard pattern, the inter-connected room matrix pattern, and the pattern of terminal rooms opening to a common corridor. This course examines the human relations that are not only cemented but also animated through the human occupation of these patterns, which leads to an understanding of modern housing against such historical background.

This course introduces to students various interpretive and analytical approaches drawn from the humanist tradition and historical studies, as well as nineteenth-century development of the Ecole des Beaux-Arts and modern anthropology, which will enable them to gain an overview of housing history in both Europe and Asia from antiquity to the present. By offering focused and in-depth studies of selected themes and cases in housing history, this course uses the house as a vehicle to enable students to reflect on, and enhance, their prior studies of architectural history and housing design.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ARCH7231 - Graduation Research Studio","description":"

The Graduation Studio in the Masters of Architecture Program is run over two terms; the first term is the
Research Studio where students develop the intellectual inquiry and research that defines their project, along
with their initial architectural proposals. The second term accommodates the Major Design Studio where
students develop this into a comprehensively resolved architecture project.

In the Research Studio students select from a series of design elective options each offering a specific
architectural proposition allied with the program streams, namely: Architecture + High Performance
Technology, Architecture + Housing, Architecture + Social Agency, and Architecture + Urban Conditions.
Emphasis is placed on theoretical research, exploration, speculation and analysis aimed at a conscious
framing of an architectural position. An ability to select appropriate architectural strategies, representation
methods, computational instruments and technical solutions will be pursued. Studio-based programs guide
the definition of a conceptual architectural proposal that describes the parameters and architectural ambitions
of individual projects. The proposal will be developed to a comprehensive level of resolution in ARCH7202:
Major Design Studio.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"6671e683dbe53450be4672f5f3961923","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3: Project Brief and Conceptual Design (Individual)","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"60","description":"

This phase is an individual enquiry focusing on the development of a detailed brief and conceptual design for your selected building/s, based on the analysis, research and principles established by the previous stages.

The conceptual design for your project should focus on the key aspects and scales important to your studio and Research Question but could include the definition of program activities and distribution, circulation, site connectivity, sustainability strategies, material and spatial strategies and structural strategies. However, it is important your work at this stage demonstrates your thinking across multiple scales; urban, building and tectonic. Plans, sections, axonometric drawings, models and perspectives should be developed that adequately describe the key components of the scheme and describe the character and quality of built form.

Assessment type: presentation and digital submission to Moodle (individual)

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"6671e683dbe53450be4672f5f3961924","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"6671e683dbe53450be4672f5f3961925","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"6e71e683dbe53450be4672f5f3961923","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"6e71e683dbe53450be4672f5f3961925","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2a71e683dbe53450be4672f5f396192c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2: Research Question and Initial Design Strategies (Individual)","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

This phase is an individual enquiry focusing on the development of a conceptual framework for your project. This involves extending the group studies with thematic-based research and developing a research question for your individual project. The Research Question is a clear statement of the focus of your project, identifying the unique scope of your investigation within the overarching studio brief – what will your project be about? What makes your project unique? Studio Leaders have identified a set of Studio Questions privileging the direction of design research project. With the first stage of investigation, in Assessment 2, you are encouraged to develop your research question from a mixture of site, precedent and thematic research accentuated by your own personal interests; whether  performative,  contextual,  social,  political,  economic, philosophical,  geographical,  technical  or typological, noting that architecture is generated by exposing potentially conflicting issues into a balanced holistic design.

For the design strategies, you will be required to explore, critique and experiment in developing a proposition that relates to your studio and research question. Depending on your studio, you may choose to explore different parameters or scales.

Assessment type: presentation and digital submission to Moodle (individual)

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"6671e683dbe53450be4672f5f3961924","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"6671e683dbe53450be4672f5f3961925","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"6671e683dbe53450be4672f5f3961926","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2e71e683dbe53450be4672f5f3961927","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Analytics – Site and Precedent (Group)","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

This phase is an intensive group research and analysis exercise focusing on studio questions, site, thematic and precedent. The process and product of this phase will constitute the analytics that are then used to develop the research focus and architectural position for your project. Work will be undertaken in groups of 4 -6 students, with each group focusing on in-depth analysis of different aspects of the site and a detailed precedent study of exemplar buildings related to the studio premise.

Analysis and learnings from site and precedent studies will be communicated through drawings and physical models as appropriate. It will be expected that this gathering will be extensive and its assemblage and presentation rigorous and professional. All drawings / information will be collated in an exhibition – a shared resource for all to use.

Assessment type: Exhibition, presentation and digital submission to Moodle (group)
