Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ARCH7251 - Graduation Major Design Studio","description":"

The Graduation Studio in the Masters of Architecture Program is run over two terms; the first term is the Research Studio where students develop the intellectual inquiry and research that defines their project, along with their initial architectural proposals. The second term accommodates the Major Design Studio where students develop this into a comprehensively resolved architecture project.


In the Major Design Studio, students continue in their previous studio group to create rigorous and compelling architecture. Each studio explicitly supports the detailed design development of individual architectural proposals as realised through appropriate modes of architectural representation. Emphasis is placed on development of the architectural proposition through critique and testing. The developed design will reach an ambitious level of programmatic, spatial, material, environmental and technological integration and resolution, with an ambitious and imaginative level of experimentation. Students will evaluate and develop architectural representation styles and techniques to establish the most effective methods to communicate their work. Presentation to peers, eminent critics and practitioners occurs through studio reviews and a public graduation exhibition.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"44812a83dbe53450be4672f5f39619d0","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Detailed Design","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Based on the Initial Design undertaken in Assessment 1, a developed set of drawings and models of your
scheme is required to articulate the formal configuration in relation to the program and inhabitation, as well
as the structural, constructional, tectonic and environmental integration. This stage requires you to develop
your project to a technical level of detail, including tectonic development up to a minimum of 1:50 (and
possibly including 1:20/1:10 and 1:5 details). To support this, this phase of the project will be supplemented
by dedicated structural, technological and environmental tutorials.

In particular, emphasis at this stage is given to developing the project through physical models and all
students should develop and present highly crafted models to demonstrate design thinking and
representation of their architecture. Liaising with the Fab Lab in terms of model craft, material and quality is
essential. Students are encouraged to use models to demonstrate the assemblage and tectonics of their
architecture (i.e. 1:50 bay study models, etc). A further developed plan for final presentation models MUST
be submitted in the form of testing models (combining different scales and materilas) and a journal. They
express an unique relationship between the 3D + material representation and your design project: concept,
approach, and solution generated by your design question.

• Verbal feedback weekly at tutorials. In the first four weeks students will receive tutorials
in groups. Thereafter tutorials will be individual. It is up to students to accurately record
verbal feedback either by writing notes, or audio recording (please ask permission from
your tutors before audio recording)
• Written feedback from assessments, including a suggestion of performance against the
assessment criteria
• Peer and guest review feedback from individual presentations.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"80812a83dbe53450be4672f5f39619d1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"80812a83dbe53450be4672f5f39619d2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"80812a83dbe53450be4672f5f39619d3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"88812a83dbe53450be4672f5f39619d1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"88812a83dbe53450be4672f5f39619d2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"88812a83dbe53450be4672f5f39619d3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"40812a83dbe53450be4672f5f39619d5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Draft Design","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Assessment 1 takes the form of a studio presentation and physical submission of work which documents the
Initial Design for your selected building/s.

As a guide, the Assessment 1 submission may include the following in a preliminary form: location/site
information, adequate plans, sections and elevations at suitable and agreed scales to explain the project; 3-
dimensional representation using drawn and/or modelling techniques (exterior, interior perspectives, site
models and sectional models as appropriate); and sufficient drawings / diagrams to indicate an adequate
knowledge and intention of the constructional, structural and servicing systems for the proposed project as
appropriate.

• Verbal feedback weekly at tutorials. In the first four weeks students will receive tutorials
in groups. Thereafter tutorials will be individual. It is up to students to accurately record
verbal feedback either by writing notes, or audio recording (please ask permission from
your tutors before audio recording)
• Written feedback from assessments, including a suggestion of performance against the
assessment criteria
• Peer and guest review feedback from individual presentations.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"80812a83dbe53450be4672f5f39619d1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"80812a83dbe53450be4672f5f39619d2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"80812a83dbe53450be4672f5f39619d3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"88812a83dbe53450be4672f5f39619d1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"88812a83dbe53450be4672f5f39619d2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"88812a83dbe53450be4672f5f39619d3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"c0812a83dbe53450be4672f5f39619dd","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Final Design (50%) and Design Report (10%)","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"60","description":"

Assessment 3 takes the form of a studio presentation which presents the Final Design for your
selected building/s. This will be the completion of 9-months of research, testing, design development and
graphical communication.

Based on the Developed Design undertaken in Assessment 2, a complete set of drawings and models
of your scheme is required to articulate the formal configuration in relation to the program and
inhabitation, as well as the structural, constructional, environmental and tectonic resolution. Particular
focus at this stage will be given to the creativity and craft of final graphical and model representations.

• Verbal feedback weekly at tutorials. In the first four weeks students will receive tutorials
in groups. Thereafter tutorials will be individual. It is up to students to accurately record
verbal feedback either by writing notes, or audio recording (please ask permission from
your tutors before audio recording)
• Written feedback from assessments, including a suggestion of performance against the
assessment criteria
• Peer and guest review feedback from individual presentations.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ARCH7252 - Graduation Major Design Studio","description":"

Students continue in projects selected in M Arch Graduation Research Studio. Each project program explicitly supports the detailed design development of individual architectural proposals as realized through appropriate modes of architectural representation. Emphasis is placed on refinement of the architectural proposition through the development of design as a graduation project. This is presented at an ambitious level of programmatic, spatial, material, environmental and technological integration and resolution, or of ambitious and imaginative level of experimentation. Presentation to peers, eminent critics and practitioners occurs through studio reviews and a public graduation exhibition.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"f081aa83dbe53450be4672f5f3961917","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1 - Initial Design","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Assessment 1 takes the form of a studio presentation and physical submission of work which documents the
Initial Design for your selected building/s.

As a guide, the Assessment 1 submission may include the following in a preliminary form: location/site
information, adequate plans, sections and elevations at suitable and agreed scales to explain the project; 3-
dimensional representation using drawn and/or modelling techniques (exterior, interior perspectives, site
models and sectional models as appropriate); and sufficient drawings / diagrams to indicate an adequate
knowledge and intention of the constructional, structural and servicing systems for the proposed project as
appropriate.

• Verbal feedback weekly at tutorials. In the first four weeks students will receive tutorials
in groups. Thereafter tutorials will be individual. It is up to students to accurately record
verbal feedback either by writing notes, or audio recording (please ask permission from
your tutors before audio recording)
• Written feedback from assessments, including a suggestion of performance against the
assessment criteria
• Peer and guest review feedback from individual presentations.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b081aa83dbe53450be4672f5f3961918","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"b081aa83dbe53450be4672f5f3961919","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b081aa83dbe53450be4672f5f396191a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"b881aa83dbe53450be4672f5f3961918","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"b881aa83dbe53450be4672f5f3961919","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b881aa83dbe53450be4672f5f396191a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4d81aa83dbe53450be4672f5f3961929","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2 – Detailed Design","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Based on the Initial Design undertaken in Assessment 1, a developed set of drawings and models of your
scheme is required to articulate the formal configuration in relation to the program and inhabitation, as well
as the structural, constructional, tectonic and environmental integration. This stage requires you to develop
your project to a technical level of detail, including tectonic development up to a minimum of 1:50 (and
possibly including 1:20/1:10 and 1:5 details). To support this, this phase of the project will be supplemented
by dedicated structural, technological and environmental tutorials.

In particular, emphasis at this stage is given to developing the project through physical models and all
students should develop and present highly crafted models to demonstrate design thinking and
representation of their architecture. Liaising with the Fab Lab in terms of model craft, material and quality is
essential. Students are encouraged to use models to demonstrate the assemblage and tectonics of their
architecture (i.e. 1:50 bay study models, etc). A further developed plan for final presentation models MUST
be submitted in the form of testing models (combining different scales and materilas) and a journal. They
express an unique relationship between the 3D + material representation and your design project: concept,
approach, and solution generated by your design question.

• Verbal feedback weekly at tutorials. In the first four weeks students will receive tutorials
in groups. Thereafter tutorials will be individual. It is up to students to accurately record
verbal feedback either by writing notes, or audio recording (please ask permission from
your tutors before audio recording)
• Written feedback from assessments, including a suggestion of performance against the
assessment criteria
• Peer and guest review feedback from individual presentations.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b081aa83dbe53450be4672f5f3961918","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"b081aa83dbe53450be4672f5f3961919","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b081aa83dbe53450be4672f5f396191a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"b881aa83dbe53450be4672f5f3961918","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"b881aa83dbe53450be4672f5f3961919","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b881aa83dbe53450be4672f5f396191a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7081aa83dbe53450be4672f5f396191c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3 – Final Design 50% + Presentation Models/Hard Material Outputs 10%","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"60","description":"

Assessment 3 takes the form of a studio presentation which presents the Final Design for your
selected building/s. This will be the completion of 9-months of research, testing, design development and
graphical communication.

Based on the Developed Design undertaken in Assessment 2, a complete set of drawings and models
of your scheme is required to articulate the formal configuration in relation to the program and
inhabitation, as well as the structural, constructional, environmental and tectonic resolution. Particular
focus at this stage will be given to the creativity and craft of final graphical and model representations.

• Verbal feedback weekly at tutorials. In the first four weeks students will receive tutorials
in groups. Thereafter tutorials will be individual. It is up to students to accurately record
verbal feedback either by writing notes, or audio recording (please ask permission from
your tutors before audio recording)
• Written feedback from assessments, including a suggestion of performance against the
assessment criteria
• Peer and guest review feedback from individual presentations.

contentlets.description: Students continue in projects selected in M Arch Graduation Research Studio. Each project program explicitly supports the detailed design development of individual architectural proposals as realized through appropriate modes of architectural representation. Emphasis is placed on refinement of the architectural proposition through the development of design as a graduation project. This is presented at an ambitious level of programmatic, spatial, material, environmental and technological integration and resolution, or of ambitious and imaginative level of experimentation. Presentation to peers, eminent critics and practitioners occurs through studio reviews and a public graduation exhibition.
contentlets.title: Graduation Major Design Studio

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ARCH7254 - Graduation Major Design Studio","description":"

The Graduation Studio in the Master of Architecture Program is run over two terms. The first term is the
Research Studio where students develop the intellectual inquiry and research that defines their project,
along with their initial architectural proposals. The second term accommodates the Major Design Studio
where students develop this into a comprehensively resolved architecture project.
In the Major Design Studio, students continue in their Research Studio group to create rigorous and
compelling architecture. Each studio explicitly supports the detailed design development of individual
architectural proposals as realised through appropriate modes of architectural representation. Emphasis is
placed on development of the architectural proposition through critique and testing. The developed design
will reach an ambitious level of programmatic, spatial, material, environmental and technological integration
and resolution, with an ambitious and imaginative level of experimentation. Students will evaluate and
develop architectural representation styles and techniques to establish the most effective methods to
communicate their work. Presentation to peers, eminent critics and practitioners occurs through studio
reviews and a public graduation exhibition.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"6e812e83dbe53450be4672f5f3961903","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2 – Detailed Design 20%","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Based on the Initial Design undertaken in Assessment 1, a developed set of drawings and models of your
scheme is required to articulate the formal configuration in relation to the program and inhabitation, as well
as the structural, constructional, tectonic and environmental integration. This stage requires you to develop
your project to a technical level of detail, including tectonic development up to a minimum of 1:50 (and
possibly including 1:20/1:10 and 1:5 details). To support this, this phase of the project will be supplemented
by dedicated structural, technological and environmental tutorials.
In particular, emphasis at this stage is given to developing the project through physical models and all
students should develop and present highly crafted models to demonstrate design thinking and
representation of their architecture. Liaising with the Fab Lab in terms of model craft, material and quality is
essential. Students are encouraged to use models to demonstrate the assemblage and tectonics of their
architecture (i.e. 1:50 bay study models, etc). A further developed plan for final presentation models MUST
be submitted in the form of testing models (combining different scales and materilas) and a journal. They
express an unique relationship between the 3D + material representation and your design project: concept,
approach, and solution generated by your design question.
By this stage, it will be likely your design will be almost complete, so students should consider this
submission a draft final completion of their project (as assessment 3 deals predominantly with production
and representation).

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"26812e83dbe53450be4672f5f3961905","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"26812e83dbe53450be4672f5f3961906","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"26812e83dbe53450be4672f5f3961907","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"2e812e83dbe53450be4672f5f3961904","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2e812e83dbe53450be4672f5f3961905","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"2e812e83dbe53450be4672f5f3961906","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7a812e83dbe53450be4672f5f396190e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3 – Final Design 50% + Presentation Models/Hard Material Outputs 10%","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"60","description":"

Assessment 3 takes the form of a studio presentation which presents the Final Design for your
selected building/s. This will be the completion of 9-months of research, testing, design development and
graphical communication.
Based on the Developed Design undertaken in Assessment 2, a complete set of drawings and models
of your scheme is required to articulate the formal configuration in relation to the program and
inhabitation, as well as the structural, constructional, environmental and tectonic resolution. Particular
focus at this stage will be given to the creativity and craft of final graphical and model representations.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"26812e83dbe53450be4672f5f3961906","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"2e812e83dbe53450be4672f5f3961904","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2e812e83dbe53450be4672f5f3961905","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"2e812e83dbe53450be4672f5f3961906","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"ea812e83dbe53450be4672f5f3961908","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1 – Initial Design 20%","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Assessment 1 takes the form of a studio presentation and physical submission of work which documents the
Initial Design for your selected building/s.
Based on your research and conceptual design testing undertaken in ARCH7201 in semester 1, key ideas
are developed through initial design, including program, site and context, 2-dimentional and/or 3-dimentional
planning strategies, formal configuration and the initial technological and technical implications on design
including structural, construction and environment. Scaled drawings and physical models (digital and
analogue) are required for this submission. While it is up to each student and studio to determine the
appropriate drawings, models and scales required, a typical submission might include plans and sections at
1:200/1:100 scale and interior and exterior perspectives demonstrating materiality, narrative and
experience. Initial technical drawings, including tectonic 1:50/1:20/1:10 sections or axonometric drawings,
structural diagrams, environmental testing and diagrams would also be beneficial for this submission.
In particular, emphasis at this stage is given to developing the project through physical models and all
students should develop and present highly crafted models to demonstrate design thinking and
representation of their architecture. You are expected to initiate a plan for model making combining the skills
obtained from the Digital Fabrication Workshop and Presentation Models Lab classes during Term 2.
Liaising with the Fab Lab in terms of model craft, material and quality is essential.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"26812e83dbe53450be4672f5f3961905","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"26812e83dbe53450be4672f5f3961906","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"26812e83dbe53450be4672f5f3961907","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"2e812e83dbe53450be4672f5f3961904","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2e812e83dbe53450be4672f5f3961905","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"2e812e83dbe53450be4672f5f3961906","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"f6812e83dbe53450be4672f5f3961916","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/ARCH7254.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"","links":[]}

of Arts, Design and Architecture","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"search_title":"ARCH7304 - Architecture and the City","description":"

The course is concerned with historical and modern cities, particularly the role of buildings in shaping urban settings. Students will learn about by this topic by reading texts, as well as making drawings and models. In this course, students are introduced to a mode of interpreting buildings, which acknowledges their urban contexts, external forms, ornaments and interiors. Ideas are explored in a series of lectures and seminars. Students may undertake joint and independent research on aspects of civic spaces and cities.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"af812e83dbe53450be4672f5f39619cf","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3. Interpret selected building significance. (Individual assignment)","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"
  • Assignment title: Interpret the significance of your selected building by reconsidering the principles addressed in assignment 2.

 

  • Each student submits a text, sketches and photographs of the model. The text has a 3,000 word limit. The text must be documented with footnotes and a bibliography. A maximum of ten sketches can be included. The initial model can be refined to highlight themes of significance for your essay. Photographs of this are included in the assignment.       

 

Assessment considers an individual student’s work and provides a mark that will count as 50%. The assessment will take into consideration the relationship between 3 facets of the submission, namely the text, the sketches and the photographs of the model.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a7812e83dbe53450be4672f5f39619d0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"a7812e83dbe53450be4672f5f39619d1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"a7812e83dbe53450be4672f5f39619d2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"af812e83dbe53450be4672f5f39619d0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"af812e83dbe53450be4672f5f39619d1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6f812e83dbe53450be4672f5f39619ea","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2: Analyse selected building. (Individual assignment)","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"
  • Assignment title: Analyse your selected building (see assignment 1). The initial ideas concerning its context of a city, suburb or landscape will be developed. Emphasis is placed on the institution, the site, the activity or ritual, the external composition and the disposition of rooms. You can allude to some of the following principles: the human analogy, order, symmetry, proportion, decorum, economy, monumentality, history and memory, ornament, and the play of light and shadow. 

Each student submits a text and sketches, as well as photographs of an exploratory model. The text has a 1,500 word limit. The text must be documented with footnotes and a bibliography. Sketches are to be made free

  • hand by the student. A maximum of eight rapid sketches can be included. A sketch model that shows a relevant aspect of the building will be made. Photographs of this are included in the assignment.

 

Assessment considers an individual student’s work and provides a mark that will count as 40%. The assessment will take into consideration the relationship between 3 facets of the submission, namely the text, the sketches and the photographs of the model.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a7812e83dbe53450be4672f5f39619d0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"a7812e83dbe53450be4672f5f39619d1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"af812e83dbe53450be4672f5f39619d0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"af812e83dbe53450be4672f5f39619d1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a3812e83dbe53450be4672f5f39619e5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1:Describe a selected building. Individual assignment (Formative assessment leading to assignment 2)","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

1. Part 1. Individual assignment; (Formative assessment leading to assignment 2)

 

  • Assessment title: Describe a selected building, in terms of its context of a city, suburb or landscape.

 

  • Each student submits a short text and accompanying sketches. The text has a 200 word limit. The text need not be documented with footnotes and a bibliography. Sketches are to be made free hand by the student. A maximum of four sketches.

 

Assessment considers an individual student’s work and provides a mark that will count as 10% of the course total.

Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"ARCH7809","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ARCH7809 - Architectural Environment & Building Services","description":"

This course introduces students to the performance of the indoor built environment, its design to provide comfort conditions and the associated building services. These include heating, ventilation and air conditioning, lighting, fire safety related services, electric systems and renewables, and hydraulic services. In completing the course, the students will master the fundamentals of building envelope design and ventilation strategies to provide thermal comfort and to assess their impact on building energy needs. Further, the students are enabled to collaborate with building services engineers and other professionals, understanding the relations between architectural space and building services. This allows students to undertake the preliminary selection and architectural integration of building services. Design exercises form part of the study.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"369162c3dbe53450be4672f5f396193c","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Building services and architectural design","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Step 1. On their design studio project (ARCH7112), the students perform a light building services integration with the selection of building services and positioning of bulk items (e.g., air handling unit, elevator, switchboard), without detailing the ducting and wiring. Deliverable: plans (all floors), sections and elevations, and short report.

Step 2. Architectural impact of building services. Show the impact of building services on architecture (i.e., how the building looks like with the machines in). Deliverable: elevations, roof plan (and interior view if needed).

Step 3. Coordination meeting preparation: a) prepare specific questions for the building services engineers, structural designer and consultants. This includes what you ask at early stages in design, etc. b) Prepare discussion focusing on the resolution of potential conflicts between architecture, structure and services. Deliverable: Report.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f29162c3dbe53450be4672f5f396193e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"fa9162c3dbe53450be4672f5f396193d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"729162c3dbe53450be4672f5f3961944","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Building envelope ","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

Plans, elevations, sections, building details and a short report including:

  • Architectural layout to minimize energy consumption
  • Annotations on the strategies to achieve thermal comfort and ventilation, shading devices integration, and management of thermal bridges, and acoustical performance of the indoor environment and building components.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f29162c3dbe53450be4672f5f396193d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f29162c3dbe53450be4672f5f396193e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"fa9162c3dbe53450be4672f5f396193d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"769162c3dbe53450be4672f5f396193f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Building services integration","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

10% Group. 20% Individual.

Step 1. Individual component (20%). On an assigned commercial building (the same building for the whole group) students integrate: HVAC, electric services, artificial lighting, & renewables, fire safety services, and hydraulic services. The deliverable includes plans (typical floor), sections and elevations, with annotations.

Step 2. Group component (10%). Integration and coordination between building services (demonstration of no interference). Deliverable: plans (typical floor only), sections and elevations, and consolidated report.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f29162c3dbe53450be4672f5f396193e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"fa9162c3dbe53450be4672f5f396193d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"be9162c3dbe53450be4672f5f396196c","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/ARCH7809.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"","links":[]}
